revision.text:
{{Infobox album |name=Alive! The Millennium Concert |type=[[Live album]] |artist=[[Kiss (band)|Kiss]] |cover= KissAliveMillenium.jpg |alt= |released=November 21, 2006 |recorded=December 31, 1999
January 1, 2000 |venue=[[BC Place|BC Place Stadium]], [[Vancouver]] |studio= |genre=[[Hard rock]] |length={{Duration|m=76|s=54}} ([[Best Buy]] edition){{cite web|url=https://www.allmusic.com/album/alive-the-millennium-concert-mw0000807170|title=Alive: The Millennium Concert - Kiss: Songs, Reviews, Credits|website=[[AllMusic]]|access-date=April 25, 2018}}
{{Duration|m=81|s=45}} ([[Phonograph record|Vinyl]] edition){{cite web|url=https://www.allmusic.com/album/release/alive-the-millennium-concert-lp-mr0004151532|title=Alive: The Millennium Concert [LP] - Kiss: Release Info|website=AllMusic|access-date=April 25, 2018}} |label=[[Mercury Records|Mercury]], [[Universal Music Group|Universal]] |producer= |prev_title=[[Kiss Instant Live]] |prev_year=2004 |next_title=[[Kiss Alive 35]] |next_year=2008}} '''''Alive! The Millennium Concert''''' is a [[Album#Live|live album]] by the [[United States|American]] [[hard rock]] [[Band (rock and pop)|band]] [[Kiss (band)|Kiss]]. It was released on November 21, 2006 as part of the ''[[Kiss Alive! 1975–2000]]'' [[box set]]. ==Album information== It was recorded on December 31, 1999 at [[BC Place|BC Place Stadium]] in [[Vancouver]], [[Canada]]{{cite web|url=https://www.setlist.fm/setlist/kiss/1999/bc-place-stadium-vancouver-bc-canada-23d72ccf.html|title=KISS Concert Setlist at BC Place Stadium, Vancouver on December 31, 1999|website=setlist.fm|access-date=April 25, 2018}} and included songs that had never before been performed by the original lineup ("[[Heaven's on Fire]]", "[[I Love It Loud]]" and "[[Lick It Up (song)|Lick It Up]]"). It was originally intended to be released as ''Alive IV'' in 2000 but was shelved when Kiss' parent label [[Mercury Records|Mercury]] was swallowed by the [[Universal Music|Universal]]/[[Vivendi]] merger. However, the album's version of "[[Rock and Roll All Nite]]" was included in ''[[The Box Set (Kiss)|The Box Set]]'' which was released on November 20, 2001.{{cite web|url=https://www.amazon.com/dp/B003E7HS4C/?coliid=I1AVSWX99SJEHP&colid=2I3KBXV5TNNB8&psc=0|title=Kiss Box Set by Kiss on Amazon Music|website=[[Amazon (company)|Amazon.com]]|access-date=April 25, 2018}} Although Universal later agreed to Kiss using Mercury to release what would become The Millennium Concert as ''Alive IV'', it was shelved indefinitely and the band would release the ''[[Kiss Symphony: Alive IV|Symphony: Alive IV]]'' album released on Kiss Records/[[Sanctuary Records]] in 2003. It was finally released on November 21, 2006 as part of the ''[[Kiss Alive! 1975–2000]]'' [[box set]]. An edition of the box set exclusive to [[Best Buy]] was advertised as including two exclusive bonus tracks (2,000 Man and God of Thunder) on ''The Millennium Concert'' disc{{cite web|url=https://www.discogs.com/Kiss-Alive-The-Millennium-Concert/release/6209194|title=Kiss - Alive: The Millennium Concert (CD, Album)|website=[[Discogs]]|access-date=April 25, 2018}}. But due to an error, Best Buy only sold the standard box set that did not have the exclusive bonus tracks. In an attempt to correct this, a replacement disc was produced and small quantities were shipped to Best Buy locations where the discs were given out to customers who came back to complain that their box did not include the promised extra tracks. Another bonus track, "[[Detroit Rock City]]", was released as an exclusive to the [[iTunes]] edition of the box set.{{cite web|url=https://itunes.apple.com/us/album/alive-1975-2000/205155994|title=Alive! (1975-2000) by Kiss on Apple Music|website=[[iTunes]]|access-date=April 25, 2018}} In October 14, 2014 ''The Millennium Concert'' was released on [[Phonograph record|vinyl]].{{cite web|url=https://www.amazon.com/Alive-Millennium-Concert-2-LP/dp/B00IVNSG6I/ref=tmm_vnl_swatch_0?_encoding=UTF8&coliid=IJCRYPJ1Z5K2F&colid=2I3KBXV5TNNB8&qid=&sr=|title=Kiss - Alive - The Millennium Concert [2 LP]|website=Amazon.com|access-date=April 25, 2018}} This edition was the first release to include the entire concert{{cite web|url=https://www.discogs.com/Kiss-Alive-The-Millennium-Concert/release/6270271|title=Kiss - Alive: The Millennium Concert (Vinyl, LP, Album)|website=Discogs|access-date=April 25, 2018}} (except for "[[Cold Gin]]" and "[[Shock Me]]" which remain unreleased). ==Track listing== {{tracklist |extra_column=Lead vocals |title1=[[Psycho Circus (song)|Psycho Circus]] |writer1=[[Paul Stanley]], Curtis Cuomo |extra1=Stanley |length1=5:33 |title2=[[Shout It Out Loud (Kiss song)|Shout It Out Loud]] |writer2=Stanley, [[Gene Simmons]], [[Bob Ezrin]] |extra2=Stanley, Simmons |length2=3:16 |title3=[[Deuce (song)|Deuce]] |writer3=Simmons |extra3=Simmons |length3=3:45 |title4=[[Heaven's on Fire]] |writer4=Stanley, [[Desmond Child]] |extra4=Stanley |length4=4:14 |title5=Into the Void |writer5=[[Ace Frehley]], Karl Cochran |extra5=[[Ace Frehley]] |length5=4:25 |title6=[[Firehouse (song)|Firehouse]] |writer6=Stanley |extra6=Stanley |length6=3:59 |title7=Do You Love Me? |writer7=Stanley, Ezrin, [[Kim Fowley]] |extra7=Stanley |length7=3:54 |title8=[[Let Me Go, Rock 'n' Roll]] |writer8=Stanley, Simmons |extra8=Simmons |length8=5:16 |title9=[[I Love It Loud]] |writer9=Simmons, [[Vinnie Vincent]] |extra9=Simmons |length9=3:24 |title10=[[Lick It Up (song)|Lick It Up]] |writer10=Stanley, Vincent |extra10=Stanley |length10=4:39 |title11=100,000 Years |writer11=Stanley, Simmons |extra11=Stanley |length11=5:47 |title12=[[Love Gun (song)|Love Gun]] |writer12=Stanley |extra12=Stanley |length12=4:17 |title13=[[Black Diamond (Kiss song)|Black Diamond]] |writer13=Stanley |extra13=[[Peter Criss]], intro by Stanley |length13=5:28 |title14=[[Beth (song)|Beth]] |writer14=Criss, Ezrin, Stan Penridge |extra14=Criss |length14=2:42 |title15=[[Rock and Roll All Nite]] |writer15=Stanley, Simmons |extra15=Simmons |length15=5:40}} {{tracklist |collapsed=no |headline=Best Buy edition |extra_column=Lead vocals |title16=2,000 Man |writer16=[[Mick Jagger]], [[Keith Richards]] |extra16=Frehley |length16=5:30 |title17=[[God of Thunder (song)|God of Thunder]] |writer17=Stanley |extra17=Simmons |length17=4:55}} {{tracklist |collapsed=no |headline=iTunes edition |extra_column=Lead vocals |title16=[[Detroit Rock City (song)|Detroit Rock City]] |writer16=Stanley, Ezrin |extra16=Stanley |length16=4:58}} ===Vinyl release=== {{tracklist |headline=Side A |title1=Psycho Circus |length1= |title2=Shout It Out Loud |length2= |title3=Deuce |length3= |title4=Heaven's on Fire |length4= |title5=Into the Void |length5=}} {{tracklist |headline=Side B |title6=Firehouse |length6= |title7=Do You Love Me? |length7= |title8=Let Me Go, Rock 'n' Roll |length8= |title9=2,000 Man |length9=}} {{tracklist |headline=Side C |title10=God of Thunder |length10= |title11=I Love It Loud |length11= |title12=Lick It Up |length12= |title13=100,000 Years |length13=}} {{tracklist |headline=Side D |title14=Love Gun |length14= |title15=Black Diamond |length15= |title16=Detroit Rock City |length16= |title17=Beth |length17= |title18=Rock and Roll All Nite |length18=}} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[https://www.discogs.com/Kiss-Alive-The-Millennium-Concert/master/720697 Kiss - Alive: The Millennium Concert at Discogs] {{Kiss}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Alive The Millennium Concert}} [[Category:2006 live albums]] [[Category:Kiss (band) live albums]] [[Category:Mercury Records live albums]] [[Category:Sequel albums]] [[Category:Universal Music Group live albums]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox website | name = Art of the Title | logo = [[File:Art of the Title logo.png|Art of the Title logo]] | screenshot = | caption = | url = [http://www.artofthetitle.com Artofthetitle.com] | type = [[Motion graphic design|Motion design]] publication | language = [[English language|English]] | owner = Art of the Title, LLC | author = Ian Albinson, Alex Ulloa | editors = Lola Landekic, Will Perkins | launch date = 2007 | current status = Active | website = [http://artofthetitle.com/ artofthetitle.com] }}
'''Art of the Title''' ('''AOTT''') is an [[online publication]] dedicated to [[title sequence]] design, spanning the film, television, conference, and video game industries. The publication is both an educational and historical resource and a contemporary publication, focusing on the creative process behind the design of title sequences. It combines interviews with filmmakers and directors, designers, and craftspeople with in-depth analyses and behind-the-scenes materials.
==Overview== Art of the Title is the leading online resource of title design, with hundreds of title sequences available to view. The site features title design from countries around the world and aims to "honor the creators and innovators who contribute to the field, discussing and displaying their work with a desire to explicate, facilitate, and instigate."<ref>{{cite news | title = About the site | publisher = Art of the Title | date = 2012 | url = http://www.artofthetitle.com/about/ | accessdate = May 11, 2014 }}</ref> [[The Independent]] has said that Art of the Title may well be the "best place to visit in search of more of these neglected wonders of film art."<ref>{{cite news | title = Time to give a little credit to the credits | publisher = The Independent | date = February 25, 2011 | url = https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/films/features/time-to-give-a-little-credit-to-the-credits-2224666.html | accessdate = May 11, 2014 }}</ref> [[Film Comment]] called the site "a praiseworthy and priceless compendium" in 2011, and said, "Art of the Title's greatest achievement has been to single out and champion the journeymen designers who painstakingly sculpt opening ephemera."<ref>{{cite news | last = Finnegan | first = Jesse P. | title = Site Specifics: ArtoftheTitle.com | publisher = Film Comment | date = 2011 | url = http://www.filmcomment.com/article/site-specifics-artofthetitle.com | accessdate = May 11, 2014 }}</ref>
Art of the Title staff have been invited to speak at industry conferences and festivals such as [[SXSW]], [[AIGA]], [[Promax Awards|PromaxBDA]], MODE Summit, Gamercamp,<ref>{{cite news | title = A Brief History of Video Game Title Design | publisher = Art of the Title | date = November 5, 2013 | url = http://www.artofthetitle.com/news/a-brief-history-of-video-game-title-design/ | accessdate = May 16, 2014 }}</ref> [[Toronto International Film Festival|TIFF]] Next Wave, [[Nordic Media Festival]],<ref>{{cite web|title=THE TITLE SEQUENCE THAT SOLD THE SHOW|url=http://www.nordiskemediedager.no/en/program/the-title-sequence-that-sold-the-show/session/|website=Nordic Media Festival|publisher=Nordic Media Festival|accessdate=12 May 2018}}</ref> and [[Turner Classic Movies|TCM]] Classic Film Festival.<ref>{{cite web|title=Talks & Events — Art of the Title|url=http://www.artofthetitle.com/about/talks-events/|website=Art of the Title|accessdate=13 June 2015}}</ref> They have also done several talks in partnership with the [[Toronto International Film Festival]]'s Reel Comfort series.
In June 2017, site editors Lola Landekic and Will Perkins hosted a screening and discussion of films by designers and filmmakers [[Saul Bass]] and [[Elaine Bass]] at the [[Smithsonian American Art Museum]] in Washington, DC.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Linthicum|first1=Ryan|title=Movies at SAAM: Summer 2017|url=https://americanart.si.edu/blog/eye-level/2017/20/55908/movies-saam-summer-2017|website=Smithsonian American Art Museum|publisher=Smithsonian American Art Museum|accessdate=12 May 2018}}</ref>
==History== Art of the Title was founded by motion designer Ian Albinson and launched in 2007 as a blog intending to highlight the design of title sequences.
In 2008, Alexander Ulloa joined the site as Head Writer. Over the next few years, the site expanded with the addition of writers and editors Lola Landekic and Will Perkins, now Managing Editor and Senior Editor, respectively.
In 2011, the Art of the Title team curated the title design section of the ''Graphic Design — Now in Production'' exhibition, co-organized by the [[Walker Art Center]] and the Smithsonian Institution's [[Cooper-Hewitt, National Design Museum]].<ref>{{cite news | title = Graphic Design: Now In Production | publisher = Walker Art Center | date = 2011 | url = http://www.walkerart.org/calendar/2011/graphic-design-now-in-production | accessdate = May 11, 2014 }}</ref> The exhibition ran from October 22, 2011 – January 22, 2012 at the Walker Art Center, Minneapolis, and then was taken on a tour including stints in New York, Los Angeles, Grand Rapids, Houston, Winston-Salem, and Providence. A comprehensive, illustrated catalogue produced by the [[Walker Art Center]] and featuring an 18-page section on title design curated and written by Art of the Title accompanies the exhibition.
In 2012, the site launched a redesign developed in partnership with New Zealand-based studio CactusLab.<ref>{{cite news | title = 2012: The Year in Review | publisher = Art of the Title | date = December 31, 2011 | url = http://www.artofthetitle.com/news/2012-the-year-in-review/ | accessdate = May 11, 2014 }}</ref> The redesign adopted a responsive structure, allowing the site to "seamlessly adapt from desktop to mobile" and to provide "better cross-referencing of data alongside new bio pages for title designers and studios."<ref>{{cite news | title = Art of the Title • Web Projects • Work • CactusLab | publisher = CactusLab | date = 2012 | url = http://www.cactuslab.com/work/art-of-the-title/ | accessdate = May 11, 2014 }}</ref>
In 2013, the site went down temporarily when its [[Iron Man 3]] article was linked from [[Robert Downey, Jr.]]'s Facebook page.<ref>{{cite news | title = 2013: The Year in Review | publisher = Art of the Title | date = December 31, 2013 | url = http://www.artofthetitle.com/news/2013-the-year-in-review/ | accessdate = May 11, 2014 }}</ref>
In April 2015, the site announced an exclusive look at the James Bond ''[[Spectre (2015 film)|Spectre]]'' title sequence, which turned out to be a [[rickroll]]. Readers' reactions ran the gamut from outrage to kudos.<ref>{{cite web|title=Art of the Title – NEW: An exclusive look... |url=https://twitter.com/ArtoftheTitle/status/583290327152250880|website=Twitter|accessdate=25 August 2015}}</ref>
===SXSW Title Design Awards=== From 2010-2014, Art of the Title facilitated and participated in the jury of the [[SXSW]] Excellence in Title Design Awards, part of the [[SXSW Film Festival]].
In 2013, Ian Albinson hosted a discussion at the title screening event, and then announced the winners at the Film Awards.<ref>{{cite news | title = 2013: The Year in Review | publisher = Art of the Title | date = December 31, 2013 | url = http://www.artofthetitle.com/news/2013-the-year-in-review/ | accessdate = May 11, 2014 }}</ref>
In 2014, Managing Editor Lola Landekic and Senior Editor Will Perkins gave a talk ahead of the Title Design Awards and hosted a discussion with filmmaker and designer Henry Hobson.<ref>{{cite news | last = Kolmar | first = Jim | title = Title Design Awards and Art of the Title Discussion Announced | publisher = SXSW | date = February 20, 2014 | url = http://sxsw.com/film/news/2014/title-design-awards-and-art-title-discussion-announced | accessdate = May 11, 2014 }}</ref>
==See also== {{portal|Film}} * ''[[Trailers from Hell]]''
==References== {{reflist}}

==External links== * [http://www.artofthetitle.com/ Official Site] * [http://www.thecredits.org/2013/09/talking-title-sequences-with-creator-of-art-of-the-title/ An interview with Ian Albinson] * [http://99percentinvisible.org/episode/episode-28-movie-title-sequences-download/ 99% Invisible Podcast – Episode 28: Movie Title Sequences ] *{{Patreon creator|id=artofthetitle|name=Art of the Title}}

The '''Baishou Dance''' or '''baishouwu''' (摆手舞, literally 'hand-waving dance') is a 500-year-old historic [[group dance]] of the [[Tujia people|Tujia]], one of 55 [[ethnic minorities in China]]. The dance uses 70 ritual [[gesture]]s to represent war, farming, hunting, courtship and other aspects of traditional life.
== Literature == The Tujia nationality Baishou dance in Xiangxi, Hunan province best reflects the ethnic flavor and ancient customs of the Tujia nationality. It is popular in Longshan county, Baojing county and Yongshun county, Xiangxi Tujia-Miao Autonomous Prefecture, Hunan province. The dance is usually performed from the third to the fifteenth day of the first lunar month. It originates from an ancestor worship ceremony and dates back nearly 1,000 years ago, according to the broken stele in the Temple of Eight Clan Leaders (Qing Dynasty) and the county annals. The Tujia nationality baishou dance integrates singing, dancing, music and opera elements. It presents numerous topics concerning history and human existence, including the creation of the world, human reproduction, migration, hunting & fishing, sericulture & weaving, slash-and-burn cultivation, ancient stories, myths and legends, and daily life. The dance uses ritual gestures. Dancers' movements and postures are powerful and aesthetic. They wave one hand, wave two hands, wave hand(s) when circling around, or wave hand(s) with foot movements. The dance, usually performed on level ground, can be classified into grand baishou and small-scale baishou. The grand baishou is performed by over 1,000 dancers when offering sacrifices to Tujia ancestors and is watched by over 10,000 spectators; the small-scale baishou is performed on a small scale when offering sacrifices to ancestors with the same family name. The music of the dance incorporates vocal accompaniment (starting song and baishou song) and musical accompaniment (drum and gong). The song changes flexibly according to the content and movements of the dance. Dancers' movements and postures indicate power and freedom and feature turning, bending knees, shaking, and lowering the body. The dance is valuable for studying the history, war, religion, migration, farming, life, courtship and folk customs of the Tujia nationality.
[[Category:Dances of China]]
{{dance-stub}}

{{Redirect|The Great White North|other uses|Great White North (disambiguation){{!}}Great White North}} {{Infobox character | color = #B11520 | name = Bob and Doug McKenzie | image = [[Image:Bob and Doug McKenzie.jpg|275px|frameless]] | caption = Promotional still from ''Strange Brew''
with Bob (left) and Doug McKenzie (right) | creator = [[Rick Moranis]] and [[Dave Thomas (actor)|Dave Thomas]] | portrayer = Rick Moranis and Dave Thomas | gender = Males | first = [[Second City Television|SCTV]] ''(September 19, 1980)'' | occupation = Television hosts, bottling line inspectors, garbage men | nickname = "Hoser", "Hosehead", "Knob" | nationality = [[Canadians|Canadian]] | spouse = | children = | relatives = }} '''Bob and Doug McKenzie''' are a pair of fictional [[Canadians|Canadian]] brothers who hosted "Great White North", a [[Sketch comedy|sketch]] which was introduced on ''[[Second City Television|SCTV]]'' for the show's third season when it moved to [[CBC Television]] in [[1980 in television|1980]]. Bob is played by [[Rick Moranis]] and Doug is played by [[Dave Thomas (actor)|Dave Thomas]]. Although created originally as filler to both satisfy and mock network [[Canadian content]] demands, the duo became a [[popular culture|pop culture]] phenomenon in both Canada and the [[United States]]. The characters were later revived for an animated series, ''[[Bob & Doug (TV series)|Bob & Doug]]'', which premiered on [[Global Television Network|Global]] in 2009.Von Riedemann, Dominic. "Global Television Show Reunites SCTV's Dave Thomas, Rick Moranis." Article at Suite101.com on July 17, 2008. ==History== [[List of Bob & Doug McKenzie appearances on SCTV|"Great White North"]] (originally known as "Kanadian Korner") is a panel show that played upon [[Culture of Canada|Canadian stereotypes]]. Bob and Doug, two dim-witted [[beer]]-swilling brothers wearing heavy winter clothing and [[touque]]s, would comment on various elements of [[Culture of Canada|Canadian life and culture]], frequently employing the [[interjection]] "[[Eh]]?" and derisively calling each other "[[hoser]]." Among the topics discussed were snow routes, the [[Canadarm|Canadian-built robot arm]] on the [[Space Shuttle]], the inappropriateness of bedtime stories about dog fights, flat tires, and "why there aren't enough parking spaces at [[Tim Hortons|take-out donut shops]].""With Beer, Back Bacon and Banter, 'SCTV's Bob & Doug Mine Comedy Gold in the 'Great White North'." Article in ''People'' magazine, February 1, 1982. [http://www.people.com/people/archive/article/0,,20081357,00.html] The sketch was conceived when ''SCTV'' moved to the CBC television network. Due to the difference in the amount of time allocated for commercials, each episode to be broadcast on that network was two minutes longer than those [[Television syndication|syndicated]] to the United States. The CBC network heads asked the show's producers to add specifically identifiably [[Canadian content]] for those two minutes. [[Rick Moranis]] and [[Dave Thomas (actor)|Dave Thomas]] thought that this was a ridiculous request, given that the show had been taped in Canada, with a mostly Canadian cast and crew, for two years. The request inspired them to create a [[parody]] that would incorporate every aspect of the humorous stereotype of Canadians.[http://ca.askmen.com/top_10/entertainment_300/308c_top_10_list.html "Great White North: Beer Nog." Top 10 SCTV Skits at ca.askmen.com] The segments were videotaped at the end of a day's shooting, with just Thomas and Moranis and a single camera operator. The sketches were for the most part improvised on the set, after which they would select the best ones for use on the program.Second City Television (SCTV) at The Museum of Broadcast Communications website [http://www.museum.tv/eotvsection.php?entrycode=secondcityt] Moranis recalled, "We went on the stage with no preparation, and did 15 [sketches]. Two of them were lousy, in three we cracked up and fell apart... maybe six were keepers." Added Dave Thomas in a 2000 interview, "Rick and I used to sit in the studio, by ourselves – almost like happy hour – drink real beers, cook [[back bacon]], literally make hot snack food for ourselves while we improvised and just talked. It was all very low key and stupid, and we thought, 'Well, they get what they deserve. This is their Canadian content. I hope they like it.'"Plume, Kenneth. "Interview with [[Dave Thomas (actor)|Dave Thomas]] (Part 1 of 5)" at movies.img.com, February 10, 2000. To their shock, the comedians found that this filler material had become the most popular part of the show. Though initially intended for Canadian TV only, some of the two-minute "Great White North" segments would find their way into U.S. versions of the 30-minute shows due to a shortage of content that week. When NBC ordered the 90-minute shows for the 1981 season, they specifically cited good affiliate feedback on the "two dumb Canadian characters" and requested that the characters be included in every program. They rode the crest of a fad, peaking in 1982-83, that produced one comedy album, ''[[The Great White North (album)|The Great White North]]'', and a movie, ''[[Strange Brew]]''. The album released by [[Anthem Records]] in Canada and [[Mercury Records]] in the US, went platinum in sales, won a [[Grammy]] nomination and broke the top ten on [[Billboard's]] Top LPs and Tapes list in March, 1982. It is noted for the song "Take Off" which featured fellow Canadian [[Geddy Lee]] of the rock group [[Rush (band)|Rush]] chorusing between the McKenzies' banter. On this album, they also sing their own improvised version of "[[The Twelve Days of Christmas (song)|The Twelve Days of Christmas]]", which is frequently played on the radio around the holidays in both Canada and the United States. While hugely popular in the U.S., the album was also #1 in Canada for six weeks, suggesting that Canadians appreciated the duo as an affectionate self-parody. The ''Strange Brew'' movie was released by [[MGM]] in 1983. While receiving only minimal praise from critics, it performed fairly well at the box office, earning $8.5 million in the U.S. alone to easily cover its skinny $5 million budget. Subsequent to its initial theatrical release in 1983, ''Strange Brew'' was released by [[MGM]] in both Beta and VHS formats and subsequently re-packaged and re-released on VHS and Laser disc by [[Turner Home Entertainment|Turner]] which acquired the [[MGM]] library in 1986, then also several times on VHS and DVD by [[Warner Brothers]] which acquired the library when Time Warner merged with Turner in 1996. ''Strange Brew'' continued to perform for [[Warner Brothers]] as a DVD title most likely because of the strong college cult following for Bob and Doug. A [[Strange Brew Soundtrack|second album]], a "soundtrack" to their movie ''Strange Brew'', was released in 1983. The album featured dialogue and music from the film, as well as new skits made specifically for the album that centered around the movie. The lead off track was appropriately entitled "This Isn't Our Second Album". The album sold poorly and was out-of-print soon after.{{cite news |url=http://www.collectionscanada.gc.ca/rpm/028020-119.01-e.php?brws_s=1&file_num=nlc008388.0434&issue_dt=December%2019%201981&type=1 |publisher=''[[RPM (magazine)|RPM]]'' |date=19 December 1981 |accessdate=2008-10-27 |title=RPM 50 Albums }}{{cite news |url=http://www.collectionscanada.gc.ca/rpm/028020-119.01-e.php?brws_s=1&file_num=nlc008388.0451&issue_dt=January%2030%201982&type=1 |publisher=''[[RPM (magazine)|RPM]]'' |date=30 January 1982 |accessdate=2008-10-27 |title=RPM 50 Albums }} The sketch's signature "Coo roo coo coo, coo coo coo coo" theme, according to Dave Thomas in an interview on ''[[CBC News: The Hour]]'', is an exaggeration of the [[flute]] music used in 60-second Canadian television nature vignettes, such as ''[[Hinterland Who's Who]]''.[http://www.hww.ca/index_e.asp Hinterland Who's Who website] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100504142122/http://www.hww.ca/index_e.asp |date=May 4, 2010 }}. ==Appearances on ''SCTV''== {{main|List of Bob & Doug McKenzie appearances on SCTV}} The duo had a total of 41 original segments on SCTV. Presumably filmed several at a time, most "Great White North" segments featured one two-minute sketch per SCTV episode. 25 segments were aired in the third season (1980–81). Most of Season 4, Cycle 1 (1981) was made up of "Great White North" repeat segments. The only new appearances were in episodes 4/1-2 and 4/1-9, the final episode of the cycle. The final episode included a wraparound storyline which heavily featured the characters. Growing in popularity, the characters returned for nine new segments in the second cycle of season 4. Cycle 2 (1981–82) featured a new "Great White North" segment in each episode. Season 4, Cycle 3 (1982) was the last season to feature the characters. The first episode's plot revolves around the growing popularity of Bob and Doug, and they are given their own variety show on ''SCTV'', which turns into a catastrophe. The characters returned in the next episode for a new segment in their traditional studio set, but it had been cut to one minute (the episode's storyline owing the reduced air time to their disastrous variety show). The two are then featured in three more new segments, each back to two minutes long, before Rick Moranis and Dave Thomas left ''SCTV'' to film ''Strange Brew''. ==Legacy== The duo revived the act in two award-winning [[television commercial]]s for [[Pizza Hut]] in 1984 and 1986 and a two-year campaign for the [[Molson]] Brewing Company in 1999 and 2000 consisting of more than a dozen television and radio commercials which aired nationally in the U.S.https://web.archive.org/web/20110224071145/http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=GbkOI6Q9dQ0 and also a series of commercials for [[Mr. Lube]] which aired in Canada in 2002. Featured as a sponsor of the "Two-Four Anniversary", a series of Red Cap Ale commercials featured the duo in 2007 along with collectible "stubbies" featuring the characters on the bottles. [[McFarlane Toys]] produced [[McFarlane Toys#The McKenzie Brothers|Bob and Doug McKenzie action figures]] in September 2000.{{cite web |url=http://www.spawn.com/toys/series.aspx?series=7 |title=>> Toys >> Movies >> The Mckenzie Brothers |publisher=Spawn.Com |date= |accessdate=2010-06-04 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100623033005/http://www.spawn.com/toys/series.aspx?series=7 |archivedate=2010-06-23 |df= }} In the 2000 video game ''[[Spyro: Year of the Dragon]]'', two characters appear in the Icy Peak level whose names are Bob and Doug. The level is a land of ice and snow, and there are references in certain areas of the level to ice skating and ice hockey, as well as a use of the phrase "Take off, hoser!". The characters the player interacts with in the level seem to speak with Canadian accents. In 2003, the fastest computer in Canada, which is used by the Department of [[Astronomy]] and [[Astrophysics]] at the [[University of Toronto]], was named after Bob and Doug. The $900,000 computer is being used to simulate supermassive black holes and collisions of galaxies. The machine, nicknamed McKenzie, has 268 gigabytes of memory and 40 terabytes of disk space, and consists of two master nodes (Bob and Doug), 256 compute nodes, and eight development nodes.http://www.execulink.com/~bobnet/news/bobdoug.html They played a variant of the act for the [[Walt Disney Pictures]] [[animated]] [[feature film]] ''[[Brother Bear]]'' and its [[Brother Bear 2|sequel]], with their characters being the voices of a pair of goofy bull [[moose]] named Rutt and Tuke. They also recorded a commentary for the movie that is seen on the [[DVD]].[https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0328880/ Accessed July 14, 2008][https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0465925/ Accessed July 14, 2008] A new special, ''[[Bob & Doug McKenzie's Two-Four Anniversary]]'', aired on May 20, 2007, on [[CBC Television]]. It is a retrospective on the history of the characters and their popularity, featuring interviews with various celebrities, classic clips, and new material featuring the pair. It includes an introduction by former Canadian [[Prime Minister of Canada|Prime Minister]] [[Paul Martin]] and a cameo appearance by [[Rush (band)|Rush]] lead singer [[Geddy Lee]]. On November 20, 2007, the special was released on DVD. The DVD, re-edited by Thomas himself, was twice as long as the broadcast and featured several classic McKenzie sketches from SCTV in their entirety, new footage filmed on the Great White North set and an hour's worth of bonus features. A Bob and Doug McKenzie bottle opener was included in every DVD."Take off, eh?" Review of ''Two-Four Anniversary'' special at www.macleans.ca {{cite web |url=http://www.macleans.ca/culture/entertainment/article.jsp?content=20070507_105097_105097 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2008-11-01 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090214053129/http://www.macleans.ca/culture/entertainment/article.jsp?content=20070507_105097_105097 |archivedate=2009-02-14 |df= }} In 2007, on [[Rush (band)|Rush]]'s ''[[Snakes & Arrows]]'' tour, a short film of Bob and Doug McKenzie was shown as an intro to the song "[[The Larger Bowl (A Pantoum)|The Larger Bowl]]"."Rush out for latest Rush Concert DVD Snakes & Arrows." Review at www.epinions.com on December 5, 2008. [[Animax Entertainment]], whose interactive division is currently headed by Dave Thomas, began producing a new animated series for the [[Global Television Network]] based on the characters debuting on April 19, 2009, simply entitled ''[[Bob & Doug (TV series)|Bob & Doug]]''. Thomas reprised the character of Doug in the new series. Moranis chose not to voice the character of Bob. The part was instead voiced by [[Dave Coulier]]. Moranis was, however, involved in the series as an executive producer.Rob Salem, [https://www.thestar.com/entertainment/Television/article/620381 "Bob & Doug taking off again"]. ''[[Toronto Star]]'', April 19, 2009. The show aired 15 episodes. In June 2017 it was announced that Moranis and Thomas would be performing a live reunion show at the Second City in Toronto to raise money for Thomas' nephew Jake who suffered a spinal cord injury earlier that year. The show featured other SCTV alumni including Dan Aykroyd, Eugene Levy, and Martin Short.{{citation needed|date=May 2018}} The [[SYFY]] network show [[List of Z Nation episodes#Season 4 (2017)|"Z-Nation" Season 4, Episode 8]] - 'Crisis of Faith', featured the main characters entering Canada, and running into RCMP officers, a Hockey team bearing the Canada logo and of course, zombies very reminiscent of Bob & Doug McKenzie. The cast members who confront the look-alikes used the GWN catch phrases "eh", and "hoser" among others.{{Cite web|title=Z Nation proves that Canadian zombies can be much more polite|first=Alex|last=McLevy|date=November 17, 2017|website=[[The A.V. Club]]|url=https://www.avclub.com/z-nation-proves-that-canadian-zombies-can-be-much-more-1820525273}} ==Opinions of the creators== In Dave Thomas's behind-the-scenes book on ''[[Second City Television|SCTV]]'', he reports that he and Moranis disliked the characters because they felt the network forced the characters on them and that they, as actors, were overly identified with the dimwitted, beer-drinking duo. However, in an interview accompanying the ''Two-Four Anniversary'' premiere, Thomas credited the McKenzie Brothers as a successful comedic creation of which he was quite proud. ==Discography== *''[[The Great White North (album)|Bob & Doug McKenzie: The Great White North]]'', 1981. *''[[Strange Brew (soundtrack)|Bob & Doug McKenzie: Strange Brew]]'', 1983. ==See also== *[[Beer in Canada]] *[[Canadian English]] *[[Canadian humour]] *''[[The Red Green Show]]'' *''[[Trailer Park Boys]]'' ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== * {{IMDb title | id=0086373 | title=Strange Brew}} * [http://sctvguide.ca/episodes/sctv_s3.htm Season 3 of SCTV] * [http://www.bobanddoug.com/ BobAndDoug.com] * [http://www.execulink.com/~bobnet/hoser/ The Hoser Newspaper] {{Bob & Doug McKenzie}} {{SCTV}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Mackenzie, Bob and Doug}} [[Category:Comedy sketches]] [[Category:Comedy characters]] [[Category:Canadian comedy duos]] [[Category:Television duos]] [[Category:SCTV characters]] [[Category:Fictional Canadian people|McKenzie, Bob and Doug]] [[Category:Fictional families]] [[Category:Canadian identity]] [[Category:Fictional characters introduced in 1980]] [[Category:Juno Award for Comedy Album of the Year winners]] [[Category:Anthem Records artists]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox video game |title = Bugs Bunny Lost in Time |image = Bugs Bunny - Lost in Time (game box art).jpg |caption = PlayStation cover art |developer = [[Behaviour Interactive]] |publisher = [[Infogrames]] |engine = |released = '''PlayStation'''
{{vgrelease|NA|May 31, 1999|EU|June 29, 1999}}'''Microsoft Windows'''
{{vgrelease|NA|September 30, 1999|EU|1999}} |genre = [[Platform game|Platform]] |composer = Gilles Léveillé |modes = [[Single-player]] |platforms = {{plainlist| * [[PlayStation (console)|PlayStation]] * [[Microsoft Windows]]}} }} '''''Bugs Bunny: Lost in Time''''' is a ''[[Looney Tunes]]'' [[Platform video game|platform]] [[video game]] released for the [[PlayStation (console)|PlayStation]] and [[Microsoft Windows]] in 1999. An indirect sequel, ''[[Bugs Bunny & Taz: Time Busters]]'', was released for the same platforms in 2000. ==Plot== The game stars cartoon character [[Bugs Bunny]] who finds and activates a time machine (mistaking it for a carrot juice dispenser) after taking a wrong turn at [[Albuquerque, New Mexico|Albuquerque]], intending to go to [[Pismo Beach]]. He ends up in Nowhere, home of a sorcerer named [[Knight-mare Hare|Merlin Munroe]]. Merlin then informs Bugs that he is lost in time and that he must travel through five different eras of time in order to collect clock symbols and golden carrots that will allow him to return to the present. ==Gameplay== The objective of this game is to collect time clocks to progress through different eras via the time machine. In Nowhere, which acts as a tutorial level, Bugs Bunny will learn the basic moves he needs to use to progress through the game. He can kick, jump, pick up objects, roll, jump into rabbit holes to move underground, tiptoe to avoid alerting other enemies, climb ropes, and use his rabbit ears like propellers to slowly descend to the ground from high places. Bugs can also move some objects to get to certain places. Enemies in the game are mostly simple to beat. Some can be defeated with a kick or a jump, while others may require Bugs to be chased by an enemy until they run out of breath, then they can be kicked in the back. There are also special abilities for Bugs to learn from Merlin much later as he progresses through the game. While in the time machine, there are five different eras (spanning 21 levels in total) for Bugs Bunny to visit. They are the Stone Age, Pirate Years, The 1930s, Medieval Period, and Dimension X. Each level has clock symbols and golden carrots for Bugs to find in the game. There are also normal carrots for Bugs to pick up, which act as a form of defense similar to rings from [[Sonic the Hedgehog]]. Carrots can be collected by finding them scattered in a level or defeating an enemy. If Bugs gets hit, he will lose 3 carrots. He can hold up to 99 carrots. There are some levels that require a full amount of carrots in order to play them. After completing a level, Merlin will appear and the player can decide if they wish to save their progress up to that point. At the end of each era, Bugs must confront and defeat a boss character to unlock the next era. ==Development== In late 2017, beta screenshots of the game surfaced on [[YouTube]], from "Playstation Zone Volume 3". The screenshots showcased a drastically different [[art movement|art style]] from the final game, for instance a completely redesigned different 1st level. Although, level assets are used in the final version of the game. https://youtube.com/watch/xjBc_J_EdoU Beta footage from the same source surfaced a year later.https://youtube.com/watch/YQkAI4u5rZM ==Characters== *[[Bugs Bunny]] - The main character of the game, voiced by [[Billy West]]. He is a rabbit who outwits his enemies on his quest to return to the present. *[[Knight-mare Hare|Merlin Munroe]] - A sorcerer who tells Bugs useful information to get back to the present. His name is a pun on [[Marilyn Monroe]]. He is voiced by [[Jess Harnell]]. *[[Elmer Fudd]] - A caveman who hunts "wabbits." He is the antagonist of the Stone Age Era, and is voiced by West. *[[Daffy Duck]] - Bugs' rival who is hunted by Elmer Fudd in the Stone Age and appears with his [[Robin Hood Daffy|'Robin Duck']] persona in the Medieval Period. He is voiced by [[Joe Alaskey]]. *[[Witch Hazel (Looney Tunes)|Witch Hazel]] - A witch who wants Bugs for her rabbit stew. She lives in the Forgotten Woods and appears in the Medieval Period. She is voiced by [[June Foray]]. *[[Yosemite Sam]] - Appears as the captain of a pirate ship who Bugs battles on Treasure Island in the Pirate Years. He is voiced through archive vocals by [[Mel Blanc]]. *[[Rocky and Mugsy]] - Gangster thugs who rob banks in the 1930s. They are voiced by Alaskey. *[[Marvin the Martian]] - A Martian who tests his latest weapon on Bugs Bunny. He appears in Dimension X, and is voiced by Alaskey. *'''Instant Martians''' - Martians who start out as pills will turn into martians when water is added. They appear as obstacles in Dimension X. *[[Blacque Jacque Shellacque]] - Appears as a common enemy in the Pirate Years (where his ''[[Bonanza Bunny]]'' appearance is used) and the 1930s. *'''Toro the Bull''' - A Spanish bull who is outsmarted by Bugs in a bullfight in the 1930s. *[[Beaky Buzzard]] - A sleepy buzzard who helps Bugs reach a high place when he is played a groovy tune. Appears in the Royal Square in the Medieval Period of the game. ==Reception== {{Video game reviews | width = 26m | GR = (PS) 68.33%{{cite web |url=http://www.gamerankings.com/ps/196839-bugs-bunny-lost-in-time/index.html |title=Bugs Bunny: Lost in Time for PlayStation |publisher=[[GameRankings]] |accessdate=November 17, 2014}}
(PC) 53.75%{{cite web |url=http://www.gamerankings.com/pc/196838-bugs-bunny-lost-in-time/index.html |title=Bugs Bunny: Lost in Time for PC |publisher=GameRankings |accessdate=November 17, 2014}} | Allgame = (PS) {{Rating|3.5|5}}{{cite web |last=Nguyen |first=Cal |url=http://www.allgame.com/game.php?id=18757&tab=review |title=Bugs Bunny: Lost in Time (PS) - Review |publisher=[[AllGame]] |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141117035557/http://www.allgame.com/game.php?id=18757&tab=review |archivedate=November 17, 2014 |accessdate=November 17, 2014}}
(PC) {{Rating|1.5|5}}{{cite web |last=Cook |first=Brad |url=http://www.allgame.com/game.php?id=19043&tab=review |title=Bugs Bunny: Lost in Time (PC) - Review |publisher=AllGame |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141117035926/http://www.allgame.com/game.php?id=19043&tab=review |archivedate=November 17, 2014 |accessdate=November 17, 2014}} | EGM = 4.5/10{{cite journal |title=Bugs Bunny: Lost in Time |magazine=[[Electronic Gaming Monthly]] |year=1999}} | GI = 5.25/10{{cite journal |last=Reiner |first=Andrew |url=http://gameinformer.com/reviews/review_detail.cfm?ITEM_ID=4545 |title=Bugs Bunny: Lost in Time (PS) |magazine=[[Game Informer]] |issue=76 |date=August 1999 |page=65 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20000521222128/http://gameinformer.com/reviews/review_detail.cfm?ITEM_ID=4545 |archivedate=May 21, 2000 |deadurl=yes |accessdate=November 17, 2014}} | GSpot = (PS) 7.8/10{{cite web |last=Stahl |first=Ben |date=July 8, 1999 |url=http://www.gamespot.com/reviews/bugs-bunny-lost-in-time-review/1900-2545992/ |title=Bugs Bunny: Lost in Time Review (PS) |publisher=[[GameSpot]] |accessdate=November 16, 2014}}
(PC) 6.1/10{{cite web |last=Stahl |first=Ben |date=November 18, 1999 |url=http://www.gamespot.com/reviews/bugs-bunny-lost-in-time-review/1900-2538243/ |title=Bugs Bunny: Lost in Time Review (PC) |publisher=GameSpot |accessdate=November 17, 2014}} | IGN = 7.8/10{{cite web |last=Harris |first=Craig |date=July 1, 1999 |url=http://www.ign.com/articles/1999/07/02/bugs-bunny-lost-in-time |title=Bugs Bunny: Lost in Time (PS) |publisher=[[IGN]] |accessdate=November 17, 2014}} | OPM = {{Rating|3.5|5}}{{cite journal |title=Bugs Bunny: Lost in Time |magazine=[[Official U.S. PlayStation Magazine]] |year=1999}} | PCZone = 24%{{cite journal |last=Woods |first=Dave |url=http://computerandvideogames.com/article.php?id=2792 |title=PC Review: Bugs Bunny: Lost In Time |magazine=[[PC Zone]] |year=1999 |accessdate=November 17, 2014}}{{dead link|date=September 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}} }} The game was met with average to very mixed reception, as [[GameRankings]] gave it a score of 68.33% for the PlayStation version, and 53.75% for the PC version. {{clear}} ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *{{moby game|id=/bugs-bunny-lost-in-time}} {{Bugs Bunny video games}} [[Category:1999 video games]] [[Category:3D platform games]] [[Category:Video games based on Looney Tunes]] [[Category:PlayStation (console) games]] [[Category:Windows games]] [[Category:Video games about time travel]] [[Category:Video games set in the 1930s]] [[Category:Video games featuring Bugs Bunny]] [[Category:Behaviour Interactive games]] [[Category:Video games developed in Canada]]
