revision.text:
'''Prostitution in Zimbabwe''' and related acts, including [[solicitation]], [[Procuring (prostitution)|procuring]], and keeping a [[brothel]], are illegal<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/hrrpt/2002/18234.htm |title=Zimbabwe - Country Reports on Human Rights Practices - 2002 |publisher=United States Department of State |date=2003-03-31 |accessdate=2010-01-25}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Legislation of Interpol member states on sexual offences against children Zimbabwe |url= http://www.interpol.int/Public/Children/SexualAbuse/NationalLaws/CsaZimbabwe.pdf |website=Interpol|accessdate=2 April 2018|date=2006 |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20070821233103/http://www.interpol.int/Public/Children/SexualAbuse/NationalLaws/CsaZimbabwe.pdf |archive-date=21 August 2007}}</ref> but thriving.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/world/africa/article3624252.ece |title=Zimbabwean children who sell their bodies ten times a day just to buy bread |first=Catherine |last=Philp |publisher= |work=The Times |date=March 26, 2008 |accessdate=2010-01-25 | location=London}}</ref><ref>[http://www.zimbojam.com/pics-video/in-pictures/everyday-zimbabwe/item/473-moving-prostitution-behind-closed-gates Moving Prostitution behind Closed Gates Zimbo Jam Oct 5 2012] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130114221930/http://www.zimbojam.com/pics-video/in-pictures/everyday-zimbabwe/item/473-moving-prostitution-behind-closed-gates |date=2013-01-14 }}</ref> [[Zimbabwe]]'s dire economic situation has forced many women into sex work.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.trcbnews.com/mothers-in-zimbabwe-turn-to-prostitution-despite-aids-epidemic/118777/ |title=Mothers In Zimbabwe Turn To Prostitution Despite AIDS Epidemic. TRCB News August 15, 2012}}</ref>{{sfn|Ncube|1989}}
== History == In the 1890s the [[Second Boer War]] dispersed the sex trade there, and consequently created new problems in what was then [[Southern Rhodesia]]. Public pressure led to the passage of immorality legislation in 1900.<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=zurzausxnAIC Tsuneo Yoshikuni. African Urban Experiences in Colonial [[Zimbabwe]]: A Social History of Harare Before 1925. African Books Collective, 2007.] {{ISBN|9781779220547}}</ref>
Prior to independence (1980) colonial vagrancy laws were used against sex workers. In 1983 there was a major effort to eliminate sex work in post-independence Zimbabwe by rounding up hundreds of women and detaining them until they could prove they were not involved in the trade, otherwise they were sent to resettlement camps. A number of women's groups supported this as strengthening marriage.<ref>[https://www.jstor.org/discover/10.2307/3178033?uid=2&uid=4&sid=21101939607837 Gay W. Seidman. Women in Zimbabwe: Postindependence Struggles. Feminist Studies Vol. 10, No. 3 (Autumn, 1984), pp. 419-440]</ref><ref>[https://books.google.com/books?hl=en&lr=&id=nwItHXkm25cC S Jacobs, T Howard. Women in Zimbabwe: Stated policy and State action, in Haleh Afshar 9ed. Women, State, and Ideology: Studies from Africa and Asia. SUNY Press, 1987] {{ISBN|9780791494332}}</ref>
As with many African countries, the onset of [[HIV/AIDS]] dramatically increased the interest in sex work.{{sfn|Magaisa|2001}}
== Law and politics == Prostitution is addressed in Part III of the Criminal Law (Codification and Reform) Act 2004.
The police can arrest any woman walking (in the streets) after 7pm.<ref name=dn125>[http://www.newsday.co.zw/2012/12/05/mp-fumes-over-sex-workers/ MP fumes over sex workers News Day Dec 5 2012]</ref>
In 2011 [[Thabita Khumalo]], a [[MDC-T]] MP, proposed that prostitution in Zimbabwe be decriminalised. She stated that decriminalizing prostitution would address three important issues: corruption, HIV/Aids and women’s rights.<ref>[http://nzcn.wordpress.com/2011/12/16/mdc-pushing-to-legalize-prostitution/ MDC pushing to legalize prostitution. Zimbabwean Community Network Dec 11 2011]</ref> Khumalo, who has suggested that the word ''prostitute'' be changed to ''pleasure engineer'', has continued her campaign despite being demoted in her party in 2012. She has claimed her position on the issue may have contributed to this. She is supported by the [[Zimbabwe Women’s Resource Centre and Network]] (ZWRCN),<ref name=dn125/> in addition to sex workers themselves.<ref>[http://www.zimeye.org/?p=58353 Prostitutes back Thabitha Khumalo. ZimEye July 21 2012]</ref>
The UK based [[Open Society Foundation]] reported in 2012 that the police are the greatest abusers of sex workers in Zimbabwe.<ref>[http://www.bulawayo24.com/index-id-news-sc-national-byo-17933-article-Zimbabwe+police+worst+abusers+of+prostitutes.html Zimbabwe police worst abusers of prostitutes]. Bulawayo 24 July 23, 2012</ref>
==Sex trafficking== {{see also|Human trafficking in Zimbabwe}} Zimbabwe is a source, transit, and destination country for women and children subjected to [[sex trafficking]]. Women and girls from Zimbabwean towns bordering [[South Africa]], [[Mozambique]], and [[Zambia]] are subjected to sex trafficking in brothels catering to long-distance truck drivers on both sides of the borders. Zimbabwean women and children are subjected to sex trafficking in cities and surrounding towns. Reports indicate that adults have recruited girls for child sex trafficking in [[Victoria Falls]]. The practice of ngozi, giving a family member to another family to avenge the spirits of a murdered relative, creates a vulnerability to trafficking.<ref name="state17">{{cite web|title=Zimbabwe 2017 Trafficking in Persons Report|url=https://www.state.gov/j/tip/rls/tiprpt/countries/2017/271316.htm|website=U.S. Department of State|accessdate=2 February 2018}}{{PD-notice}}</ref>
Zimbabwean women are lured into hospitality largely in neighbouring countries and some women become victims of [[forced prostitution]]. Women are exploited in sex trafficking in [[Kuwait]] and [[Saudi Arabia]]. Many Zimbabwean adult and child migrants enter South Africa with the assistance of taxi drivers who transport them to the border at [[Beitbridge]] or nearby unofficial crossing locations and are subject to sex trafficking. Some of the migrants are transferred to criminal gangs that subject them to [[forced prostitution]] in [[Musina]], [[Pretoria]], [[Johannesburg]], or [[Durban]]. Refugees from [[Somalia]] and [[Democratic Republic of the Congo]] reportedly travel from Zimbabwe’s Tongogara Refugee Camp to [[Harare]], where they are forced into prostitution.<ref name="state17" />
The [[United States Department of State]] [[Office to Monitor and Combat Trafficking in Persons]] ranks Zimbabwe as a '[[Trafficking in Persons Report#Ranking System|Tier 2 Watch List]]' country.<ref name="state17" />
== See also == {{portal|Zimbabwe}} *[[Index of Zimbabwe-related articles]] *[[Prostitution in Africa]]

New Zimbabwe 11/12/2009] *[http://www.newsday.co.zw/2013/01/12/the-tougher-side-of-prostitution/ The tougher side of prostitution. News Day Jan 12 2013]

Feltoe. A guide to the criminal law of Zimbabwe. Legal Resources Foundation, 2004

{{Use mdy dates|date=November 2015}} {{Infobox film | name = Puss in Boots | image = Puss in Boots Poster.jpg | caption = Theatrical release poster | alt = Theatrical poster showing a orange cat wearing a hat with a feather on, boots and a cape, in the black background. | director = [[Chris Miller (animator)|Chris Miller]] | producer = {{plainlist| * Joe M. Aguilar * Latifa Ouaou }} | screenplay = [[Tom Wheeler (writer)|Tom Wheeler]] | story = {{plain list| * [[Brian Lynch (writer)|Brian Lynch]] * [[William Davies (screenwriter)|Will Davies]] * Tom Wheeler }} | starring = {{plain list| * [[Antonio Banderas]] * [[Salma Hayek]] * [[Zach Galifianakis]] * [[Billy Bob Thornton]] * [[Amy Sedaris]] }} | music = [[Henry Jackman]] | editing = Eric Dapkewicz | studio = [[DreamWorks Animation]]<ref name="afi">{{cite web|title=Puss in Boots|url=http://catalog.afi.com/Catalog/moviedetails/68120|website=[[AFI Catalog of Feature Films]]|accessdate=March 11, 2018}}</ref> | distributor = [[Paramount Pictures]]<ref name="afi" /> | released = {{Film date|2011|10|16|[[MS Allure of the Seas|Allure of the Seas]]|2011|10|28|United States}} | country = United States | language = English | runtime = 90 minutes | budget = $130 million<ref>{{cite news|url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/entertainmentnewsbuzz/2011/10/box-office-puss-in-boots-in-time-rum-diary.html|title=Movie Projector: 'Puss in Boots' to stomp on competition|last=Kaufman|first=Amy|work=[[Los Angeles Times]]|publisher=[[Tribune Company]]|date=October 27, 2011|accessdate=October 27, 2011}}</ref> | gross = $555 million<ref name="Box Office">{{cite web|url=http://boxofficemojo.com/movies/?page=main&id=pussinboots12.htm|title=Puss in Boots|work=Box Office Mojo|accessdate=July 1, 2012}}</ref> }}
'''''Puss in Boots''''' is a 2011 American [[Computer animation|computer-animated]] [[Comedy film|adventure-comedy film]]<ref name="AllMovie entry">{{cite web|url=https://www.allmovie.com/movie/puss-in-boots-v490433|title=Puss in Boots (2011)|work=AllMovie|accessdate=September 9, 2018}}</ref> produced in [[3D film|3D]] format by [[DreamWorks Animation]] and distributed by [[Paramount Pictures]]. Written by [[Brian Lynch (writer)|Brian Lynch]] and [[Tom Wheeler (writer)|Tom Wheeler]], the film was directed by [[Chris Miller (animator)|Chris Miller]], who also directed ''[[Shrek the Third]]'' (2007). It stars [[Antonio Banderas]], [[Salma Hayek]], [[Zach Galifianakis]], [[Billy Bob Thornton]] and [[Amy Sedaris]]. The film follows the character [[Puss in Boots (Shrek)|Puss in Boots]] on his adventures prior to his first appearance in ''[[Shrek 2]]'' (2004). Accompanied by his friends, [[Humpty Dumpty]] and Kitty Softpaws, Puss is pitted against Jack and Jill, two murderous outlaws in ownership of legendary magical beans that lead to a great fortune.
The character of Puss in Boots originated in a [[Puss in Boots|European fairy tale in 1697]], and the film is a [[Spin-off (media)|spin-off]] and [[prequel]] to the [[Shrek (franchise)|''Shrek'' franchise]]. The film was released in theaters on October 28, 2011, in [[Digital 3D]] and [[IMAX|IMAX 3D]].<ref name="ReleaseDate">{{cite news|title=Holiday Movie Release Date Moves: A Recap|url=http://www.deadline.com/2011/09/release-date-moves-a-recap/|accessdate=October 2, 2011|newspaper=Deadline|date=September 30, 2011}}</ref><ref name=GNIMAX /> ''Puss in Boots'' grossed $554.9 million at the box office and was nominated for [[Academy Award for Best Animated Feature|Best Animated Feature]] at the [[84th Academy Awards]]. A television series spin-off from the film titled ''[[The Adventures of Puss in Boots]]'' premiered on [[Netflix]] in 2015.<ref name=PRNLegendaryPanache /> A sequel titled ''Puss in Boots 2: Nine Lives & 40 Thieves'' was scheduled for release in 2018<ref name=CSShiftsTwo /> but was removed from the studio's schedule in early 2015.<ref name=DeadlineCut500Jobs />
On November 6, 2018, it was reported by [[Variety (magazine)|Variety]] that [[Chris Meledandri]] had been tasked to reboot both ''Shrek'' and ''Puss in Boots'', with the original cast potentially returning.<ref name=ShrekReboot>{{Cite news|url=https://variety.com/2018/film/news/shrek-puss-in-boots-reboot-1203020785/|title=‘Shrek,’ ‘Puss in Boots’ Getting Rebooted (EXCLUSIVE)|last=Staff|first=Variety|date=2018-11-06|work=Variety|access-date=2018-11-06|language=en-US}}</ref><ref name=ShrekRebootAnimation>{{cite web|title=‘Shrek’ & ‘Puss in Boots’ Rebooting at Universal with Chris Meledandri|url=http://www.animationmagazine.net/features/shrek-puss-in-boots-rebooting-at-universal-with-chris-meledandri/|website=Animation Magazine|accessdate=November 6, 2018|date=November 6, 2018}}</ref>
==Plot== [[Puss in Boots (Shrek)|Puss in Boots]] ([[Antonio Banderas]]) is a talking cat named for his signature pair of boots. Puss is a fugitive on the run from the law, looking to restore his lost honor. He learns that the outlaw couple Jack ([[Billy Bob Thornton]]) and Jill ([[Amy Sedaris]]) have the magic beans he has been looking for most of his life, which can lead him to a giant's castle holding valuable golden goose eggs. When Puss tries to steal them from the outlaws' room, a female cat named Kitty Softpaws ([[Salma Hayek]]) interrupts, and both fail. Kitty is allied with Humpty Alexander Dumpty ([[Zach Galifianakis]]), a talking egg and Puss' long-estranged childhood friend from the orphanage where he was raised. Puss tells Kitty his [[origin story]] and of his feelings of betrayal for a youthful misadventure when Humpty tricked Puss into helping commit a bank robbery in his hometown of San Ricardo; Puss has been on the run ever since. Humpty eventually convinces Puss to join them in finding the beans and retrieving the golden eggs.
The trio steal the beans from Jack and Jill and plant them in the desert. Puss and Kitty's relationship becomes romantic. The trio ride the beanstalk into the clouds to find the castle of the late giant, while avoiding the Great Terror, a giant goose that guards the Golden Goose. When they realize the golden eggs are too heavy to carry, they steal the Goose, which is just a [[Goose|gosling]], and escape the castle. While celebrating their victory, the group is ambushed by Jack and Jill, who knock Puss unconscious.
When Puss wakes up, he tracks Jack and Jill to San Ricardo where he learns the entire heist was a plot by Humpty to lure him home to be arrested, as revenge for abandoning him to the authorities when Humpty's youthful heist went bad. Jack, Jill, and Kitty were involved in the con. After pleas from Imelda, his adoptive mother, Puss turns himself in to the guards while Humpty donates many golden eggs to the town and becomes a hero.
While in prison, Puss meets the original Jack from "[[Jack and the Beanstalk]]" who warns him that the Great Terror is in fact the Goose's mother, and it will stop at nothing to get its child back. Realizing Humpty intended to destroy the town all along, Puss lets a repentant Kitty help him break out of prison and she also tells him she loves him. Tracking him down just as the Great Terror arrives, Puss convinces Humpty to help him fight off the Great Terror, saying he knows Humpty is a good person at heart. Using the Goose as bait, Puss and Humpty lure the Great Terror out of the town. During the chase, Jack and Jill betray Humpty and try to take the Goose, but get crushed by the Great Terror. Humpty and the Goose are knocked off a bridge with Puss holding onto them. Humpty knows Puss cannot hold both of them, so he lets go, sacrificing himself to save the Goose and the town. Humpty's shell cracks open to reveal he was a golden egg on the inside. The Great Terror then takes the Goose and Humpty back to the giant's castle.
Puss' efforts to save San Ricardo make him a hero among the townspeople and Imelda. In the epilogue, Jack and Jill are recovering from their injuries, Humpty is shown once again in his regular egg form, wearing a golden egg suit, as he rides the Great Terror into the clouds, and Puss and Kitty kiss.
==Cast== [[File:Chat potté 3.jpg|thumb|[[Salma Hayek]], [[Antonio Banderas]] and [[Puss in Boots (Shrek)|Puss in Boots]] at a premiere of the film in [[Paris]].]] *[[Antonio Banderas]] as [[Puss in Boots (Shrek)|Puss in Boots]], a fugitive from the law and a hero of San Ricardo. *[[Zach Galifianakis]] as [[Humpty Dumpty (Shrek)|Humpty Alexander Dumpty]], the mastermind who intends to retrieve the Golden Eggs from the one-of-a-kind Goose. *[[Salma Hayek]] as [[List of Shrek characters#Kitty Softpaws|Kitty Softpaws]], a street-savvy [[Bicolor cat|Tuxedo cat]] who is Puss' female counterpart and love interest. *[[Billy Bob Thornton]] and [[Amy Sedaris]] as [[List of Shrek characters#Jack and Jill|Jack and Jill]], a murderous outlaw husband and wife couple. *[[Constance Marie]] as Imelda, Puss' human adoptive mother *[[Guillermo del Toro]] as Comandante, Moustache Man *[[Mike Mitchell (director)|Mike Mitchell]] as Andy "Jack" Beanstalk
==Production== The film had been in development since 2004, when ''[[Shrek 2]]'' was released.<ref>{{cite news |author=Australian Associated Press |author-link=Australian Associated Press |url=http://www.smh.com.au/articles/2004/06/09/1086749781669.html |title=Banderas walks Shrek's green carpet |work=[[The Sydney Morning Herald]] |date=June 10, 2004 |accessdate=December 9, 2010}}</ref> As a ''Shrek 2'' spin-off, it was initially planned for release in 2008 as a [[direct-to-video]] film,<ref>{{cite news |first=Ben |last=Fritz |url=http://www.variety.com/article/VR1117929100 |title=D'Works will rely on animal instinct |work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]] |date=September 14, 2005 |accessdate=December 9, 2010}}</ref> then titled ''Puss in Boots: The Story of an Ogre Killer''.<ref>{{cite news|last=Carroll|first=Larry|title=Movie File: Antonio Banderas, Rob Schneider, Jack Black, Vince Vaughn, Jennifer Aniston|url=http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1527400/movie-file-antonio-banderas-rob-schneider.jhtml|accessdate=October 27, 2011|newspaper=MTV|date=March 30, 2006}}</ref> By October 2006, the film was re-slated as a theatrical release due to market conditions,<ref>{{cite press release|author1=DreamWorks Animation|title=DreamWorks Animation Reports Third Quarter 2006 Financial Results|url=http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/dreamworks-animation-reports-third-quarter-2006-financial-results-56643207.html|publisher=PRNewswire|accessdate=May 14, 2015|date=October 31, 2006}}</ref> and due to DreamWorks Animation's realization that the Puss character deserved more.<ref name="DeadlineOscars" />
In September 2010, [[Guillermo del Toro]] signed on as executive producer.<ref>{{cite news |first=Borys |last=Kit |url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/guillermo-del-toro-dreamworks-ani-28354 |title=Guillermo del Toro, DreamWorks Ani strike deal |work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]] |date=September 27, 2009 |accessdate=September 27, 2010}}</ref> Discussing del Toro, Miller stated: "We worked out a system for him to come in once every few months or whenever we had something new to show him. If we needed someone to bounce ideas off of, he was always there, and if we had a problem we were tackling, we'd get Guillermo on the red phone – our emergency phone – and ask him advice on what we should do with a certain character or scene. It was like having our own film school." Miller stated that del Toro was particularly involved in Humpty's character design. "Guillermo loved the dreamy quality of Humpty Dumpty. He suggested we push that further, make him more like [[Leonardo da Vinci|da Vinci]]."<ref name="DeadlineOscars">{{cite web |first=Cari|last=Lynn |url=http://www.deadline.com/2012/02/oscars-puss-in-boots-chris-miller/ |title=OSCARS: Puss In Boots -- Chris Miller |work=[[Deadline Hollywood]] |date=February 19, 2012 |accessdate=February 27, 2012}}</ref> It was del Toro's idea to make Humpty "an ingenious freak of nature" who builds contraptions such as a flying machine.<ref name="WSJ">{{cite news |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052970204346104576639502674772230 |title=An Odd Couple and a Well-Shod Cat |last=Dodes |first=Rachel |work=online.wsj.com |date=October 21, 2011 |accessdate=January 25, 2013}}</ref> Del Toro rewrote the ending to redeem the character and deepen his relationship with Puss – an unconventional conclusion for a children's film.<ref name="Collider" /> He helped design the fantasy elements of the giant's castle, as well as the architecture of the town, which he conceived as "an amalgam of Spain and Mexico".<ref name="WSJ" />
Except for Puss, the film features new characters. Citing the co-writer, [[David H. Steinberg]], "It doesn't overlap with ''[[Shrek]]'' at all. Partly that was done to tell an original Puss story, but partly because we didn't know what ''Shrek 4'' were going to do with the characters and we couldn't write conflicting storylines."<ref>{{cite news |author="Caffeinated" Clint |url=http://www.moviehole.net/200919424-exclusive-puss-in-boots-scribe-talks |title=Exclusive : Puss in Boots scribe talks |work=Moviehole.net |date=June 8, 2009 |accessdate=December 9, 2010}}</ref> The film was teased in ''[[Shrek Forever After]]'', when Shrek finally shuts the book titled "Shrek", and puts it away next to a book titled "Puss in Boots".
''Puss in Boots'' is the first DreamWorks Animation feature film that was partly made in India. A Bangalore studio owned by Technicolor, which had mainly worked on TV specials and DVD bonus material, spent six months animating three major scenes in the film. The outsourcing had financial advantages, with 40% less labor costs than in the US, but the primary reason for outsourcing to India was lack of personnel, due to the studio producing as many as three films a year.<ref>{{cite news|last=Verrier|first=Richard|title='Puss in Boots' showcases work by India animators for DreamWorks|url=http://www.latimes.com/business/la-fi-ct-dwa-india-20111029,0,1526743.story|accessdate=November 1, 2011|newspaper=Los Angeles Times|date=October 29, 2011}}</ref>
The release date was originally set for November 4, 2011, but was pushed a week earlier to October 28, 2011.<ref name="ReleaseDate" /> Anne Globe, head of worldwide marketing for DreamWorks Animation, said the decision to move the film's release date a week earlier was to attract parents and their children to see the film before other family-friendly movies were released in November 2011.<ref name="strategy">{{cite news|last=Kaufman|first=Amy|title=Box Office: 'Puss in Boots' wins weekend by more than a whisker (Updated)|url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/entertainmentnewsbuzz/2011/10/box-office-puss-in-boots-rum-diary.html|accessdate=October 30, 2011|newspaper=Los Angelese Times|date=October 30, 2011}}</ref>
The film was renamed ''Cat in Boots'' in the [[United Arab Emirates]] for officially unknown reasons, but it is suspected for religious and cultural reasons.<ref>{{cite web |title=Cat In Boots in 3D |work=[[The National (Abu Dhabi)|The National]] |first=James |last=Mottram |date=November 24, 2011 |url=http://www.thenational.ae/arts-culture/film/cat-in-boots-in-3d |accessdate=December 9, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=Censors' claws out for film |work=7Days |date=November 23, 2011 |url=http://www.7days.ae/article/news/national/censors-claws-out-film-31095 |accessdate=December 9, 2011 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111126025936/http://www.7days.ae/article/news/national/censors-claws-out-film-31095# |archive-date=November 26, 2011 |dead-url=yes |df=mdy-all }}</ref> According to the UAE's The National Media Council, which is responsible for censorship, the UAE didn't have any involvement in the rename and that "the decision to change the name had been made by the Hollywood studio and the movie distributors in the UAE."<ref>{{cite news|last=Sambidge|first=Andy|title=UAE says it had no role in 'Puss in Boots' renaming|url=http://www.arabianbusiness.com/uae-says-it-had-no-role-in-puss-in-boots-renaming-431761.html|accessdate=June 27, 2012|newspaper=Arabian Business|date=November 25, 2011}}</ref> Consequently, since the film's distributor was based in the UAE, the same print was syndicated to all theaters throughout the Middle East. However, the name change was limited to the film's original theatrical run, as merchandise and later regional home media release retained the film's original title.
==Soundtrack== {{Anchor|Soundtrack|Score}} {{Infobox album | italic_title = no | name = Puss in Boots | type = Film | artist = [[Henry Jackman]] | cover = | alt = | released = October 24, 2011 | recorded = | venue = | studio = | genre = [[Film score|Score]] | length = 65:51 | label = [[Sony Classical]] | producer = | prev_title = | prev_year = | next_title = | next_year = }} [[Henry Jackman]], the composer for ''Puss in Boots'', utilized folk instruments of traditional Latin music. Inspired by Spanish composer [[Manuel de Falla]], Jackman blended guitars and Latin percussion with an orchestral sound influenced by [[Claude Debussy]] and [[Maurice Ravel]].<ref>{{cite web |first=Jérémie |last=Noyer |url=http://animatedviews.com/2011/winnie-the-poohs-henry-jackman-a-first-class-composer/ |title=''Winnie The Pooh''{{'}}s Henry Jackman, a "First Class" composer |publisher=AnimatedViews.com |date=July 18, 2011 |accessdate=August 6, 2011}}</ref> Mexican guitar duo [[Rodrigo y Gabriela]] contributed to Jackman's score, and two of their songs, ''Diabolo Rojo'' and ''Hanuman'' were included in the soundtrack.<ref>{{cite web|title=Mexican Guitarists Come Home From the Cold|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/01/24/arts/music/rodrigo-y-gabriela-return-to-mexico-city-in-triumph.html|publisher=The New York Times|accessdate=February 26, 2016|date=January 23, 2012}}</ref> [[Lady Gaga]]'s song "[[Americano (song)|Americano]]" was also featured in the film.<ref>{{cite web|title=Puss In Boots Sneak Featuring Lady Gaga's Americano|url=http://www.comingsoon.net/movies/news/83393-puss-in-boots-sneak-featuring-lady-gagas-americano|accessdate=November 14, 2015|date=October 21, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Vena|first1=Jocelyn|title='Puss In Boots' and Lady Gaga's 'Americano': The Story Behind The Track|url=http://newsroom.mtv.com/2011/10/28/lady-gaga-americano-puss-in-boots-the-story-behind-the-song/|publisher=MTV|accessdate=November 14, 2015|date=October 28, 2011}}</ref> The soundtrack for the film, featuring the original score by Jackman, was released on October 24, 2011, by [[Sony Classical]].<ref>{{cite web|title='Puss in Boots' Soundtrack Details|url=http://filmmusicreporter.com/2011/10/15/puss-in-boots-soundtrack-details/|publisher=Film Music Reporter|accessdate=November 14, 2015|date=October 15, 2011}}</ref>
==Release== ''Puss in Boots'' had its world premiere on October 16, 2011, aboard the [[Royal Caribbean International]]'s cruise ship ''[[MS Allure of the Seas|Allure of the Seas]]'', docked in [[Fort Lauderdale, Florida]] at the time.<ref>{{cite press release|author1=Royal Caribbean International|title=Royal Caribbean and Dreamworks Animation Host Red Carpet Premiere of Puss in Boots Onboard Royal Caribbean's Allure Of The Seas|url=http://www.prweb.com/releases/2011/10/prweb8884739.htm|publisher=PRWeb|accessdate=August 9, 2014|date=October 17, 2011}}</ref><ref name=USATAllure>{{cite news|last1=Golden|first1=Fran|title=Allure of the Seas hosts 'Puss in Boots' premiere|url=http://travel.usatoday.com/cruises/post/2011/10/puss-in-boots-3d-premiere-allure-of-the-seas-/555410/1|accessdate=August 9, 2014|work=USA Today|date=October 19, 2011|quote=This is the greatest ship in the world, and we couldn't be any more excited to have the world premiere here.}}</ref> It was theatrically released in the United States on October 28, 2011.<ref name=USATAllure /> The film was digitally re-mastered into [[IMAX#IMAX 3D|IMAX 3D]], and was released in 268 North American IMAX theaters and at least 47 IMAX theaters outside North America.<ref name=GNIMAX>{{cite press release|author1=IMAX Corporation|title=Dreamworks Animation's Puss in Boots Charms Its Way Into IMAX October 28|url=http://globenewswire.com/news-release/2011/10/21/459243/235687/en/Dreamworks-Animation-s-Puss-in-Boots-Charms-Its-Way-Into-IMAX-October-28.html|publisher=GlobeNewswire|accessdate=August 9, 2014|date=October 21, 2011}}</ref>
===Box office=== The film grossed $149,260,504 in [[North America]], and $405,726,973 in other countries, for a worldwide total of $554,987,477.<ref name="Box Office" /> It is the eleventh highest-grossing film of 2011 and is also the third highest-grossing animated film that year behind ''[[Kung Fu Panda 2]]'' ($665.7 million) and ''[[Cars 2]]'' ($559.9 million).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://boxofficemojo.com/yearly/chart/?view2=worldwide&yr=2011&p=.htm|title=2011 Worldwide Grosses|work=[[Box Office Mojo]]|accessdate=May 26, 2012}}</ref>
In North America, the film topped the box office on its opening day with $9.6 million.<ref>{{cite news|last=Smith|first=Grady|title=Box office update: 'Puss in Boots' the cat's meow on Friday with $9.6 million|url=http://insidemovies.ew.com/2011/10/29/box-office-update-puss-in-boots-in-time-rum-diary/|accessdate=October 30, 2011|newspaper=Entertainment Weekly|date=October 29, 2011}}</ref> On its opening weekend, the film made $34,077,439,<ref name="EW1">{{cite news|last=Smith|first=Grady|title=Box office report: 'Puss in Boots' walks all over 'In Time' and 'The Rum Diary' with $34 million debut|url=http://insidemovies.ew.com/2011/10/30/box-office-report-puss-in-boots-in-time-rum-diary/|accessdate=October 30, 2011|newspaper=Entertainment Weekly|date=October 30, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=October 28-30, 2011|url=http://www.boxofficemojo.com/weekend/chart/?yr=2011&wknd=43&p=.htm|publisher=Box Office Mojo|accessdate=June 27, 2012}}</ref> topping ''[[Saw III]]''{{'}}s record ($33.6 million) for the highest [[Halloween]] weekend opening ever.<ref>{{cite news|last=Subers|first=Ray|title=Weekend Report: 'Puss' Purrs Softly|url=http://boxofficemojo.com/news/?id=3298&p=.htm|accessdate=June 27, 2012|newspaper=Box Office Mojo|date=October 31, 2011}}</ref> It retained first place during its second weekend, with $33,054,644, declining only 3%.<ref>{{cite news|last=Young|first=John|title=Box office report: 'Puss in Boots' stuns 'Tower Heist' by topping weekend with $33 mil|url=http://insidemovies.ew.com/2011/11/06/box-office-report-puss-in-boots-tower-heist/|accessdate=June 27, 2012|newspaper=Entertainment Weekly|date=November 6, 2011}}</ref>
Outside North America, on its opening weekend, it earned second place with $17.2 million.<ref>{{cite news|last=Segers|first=Frank|title=Foreign Box Office: Spielberg's 'Adventures Of Tintin' Opens Solid No. 1 Overseas|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/foreign-box-office-spielberg-adventures-tintin-255081|accessdate=June 27, 2012|newspaper=The Hollywood Reporter|date=October 30, 2011}}</ref> The film opened at #1 in both the UK with a weekend gross of £1.98 million ($3.1 million),<ref>{{cite web|author=Mayer, Nissim|title='Puss in Boots' beats 'Arthur Christmas': UK box office top 10 in full|url= http://www.digitalspy.co.uk/movies/news/a355734/puss-in-boots-beats-arthur-christmas-uk-box-office-top-10-in-full.html|publisher=Digital Spy|date=December 13, 2011|accessdate=December 14, 2011}}</ref> and Australia, with $2.98 million.<ref>{{cite web|title=Australia Box Office December 8–11, 2011|url=http://boxofficemojo.com/intl/australia/?yr=2011&wk=49&p=.htm|publisher=Box Office Mojo|accessdate=June 27, 2012}}</ref> It topped the box office outside North America on its seventh weekend with $47.1 million from 40 countries.<ref>{{cite news|last=Subers|first=Ray|title=Around-the-World Roundup: 'Puss' Climbs to First|url=http://boxofficemojo.com/news/?id=3323&p=.htm|accessdate=June 27, 2012|newspaper=Box Office Mojo|date=December 11, 2011}}</ref> It ranks as the ninth highest-grossing film of 2011 outside North America.<ref>{{cite web|title=Overseas Total Yearly Box Office|url=http://boxofficemojo.com/intl/weekend/yearly/?yr=2011&p=.htm|accessdate=March 8, 2012|publisher=[[Box Office Mojo]]}}</ref> Its highest-grossing country after North America was Russia and the CIS ($50.6 million), followed by Germany ($33.9 million) and France and the Maghreb region ($33.2 million).<ref>{{cite web|title=Puss In Boots - International Box Office Results|url=http://boxofficemojo.com/movies/?page=intl&id=pussinboots12.htm|accessdate=March 13, 2012|publisher=[[Box Office Mojo]]}}</ref>
===Critical response=== Review aggregator [[Rotten Tomatoes]] gave the film a score of 84% based on reviews from 147 critics, with an average rating of 6.8 out of 10.<ref name="RT" /> The website's consensus is, "It isn't deep or groundbreaking, but what it lacks in profundity, ''Puss in Boots'' more than makes up for with an abundance of wit, visual sparkle, and effervescent charm."<ref name="RT">{{cite web | url = http://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/1209933-puss_in_boots/| title=Puss in Boots (2011)| work = [[Rotten Tomatoes]] | publisher = [[Flixster]] | accessdate = February 15, 2012}}</ref> [[Metacritic]], which assigns a weighted average score out of 100 to reviews from mainstream critics, gives the film a score of 65% based on 24 reviews.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.metacritic.com/movie/puss-in-boots| title= Puss in Boots Reviews | publisher = [[CBS Interactive]] | work = [[Metacritic]] | accessdate =October 28, 2011}}</ref> [[CinemaScore]] polls reported that the average grade moviegoers gave the film was an "A-" on an A+ to F scale.<ref name="opening">{{cite web|url=http://www.deadline.com/2011/10/first-box-office-puss-in-boots-1-paranormal-activity-3-2-in-time-3-footloose-4-the-rum-diary-5/#more-188635|title=Snow Ices Box Office: 'Puss In Boots' #1, 'Paranormal' #2, 'In Time' #3, 'Rum Diary' #4|last=Finke|first=Nikki|website=[[Deadline Hollywood]]|publisher=[[PMC (company)|PMC]]|date=October 30, 2011|accessdate=October 30, 2011}}</ref>
Todd McCarthy of ''[[The Hollywood Reporter]]'' gave the film a positive review, saying "''Puss in Boots'' is a perfectly diverting romp that happens to showcase some of the best 3D work yet from a mainstream animated feature. Colorful, clever enough, free of cloying showbiz in-jokes, action-packed without being ridiculous about it and even well choreographed."<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/movie/puss-boots/review/252312 |title=Puss in Boots: Film Review |work=The Hollywood Reporter |date=October 23, 2011 |accessdate=July 20, 2013 |first=Todd |last=McCarthy}}</ref> Peter Debruge of ''[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]'' gave the film a positive review, saying "Puss' origin story could easily stand on its own -- a testament to clever writing on the part of its creative team and an irresistible central performance by Antonio Banderas."<ref>{{cite news|last=McNary |first=Dave |url=https://variety.com/2011/film/reviews/puss-in-boots-1117946409/ |title=Puss in Boots |publisher=Variety |date=October 23, 2011 |accessdate=July 20, 2013}}</ref> Christy Lemire of the ''[[Associated Press]]'' gave the film three out of four stars, saying "For quick, lively, family friendly entertainment, "''Puss in Boots''" works just fine, even in 3-D, which is integrated thoughtfully into the narrative and doesn't just feel like a gimmick."<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.boston.com/ae/movies/articles/2011/10/24/review_puss_in_boots_a_lively_spin_off/?rss_id=Boston.com+--+Movie+news |title=Review: `Puss in Boots' a lively spin-off |publisher=Boston.com |date=October 24, 2011 |accessdate=July 20, 2013 |first=Christy |last=Lemire}}</ref> Bill Goodykoontz of ''[[The Arizona Republic]]'' gave the film three and a half stars out of five, saying "As good as Banderas and Hayek are together, Galifianakis is better, making Humpty-Dumpty, of all people, one of the more intriguing animated characters to come along in a while. He's a nice surprise."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.azcentral.com/thingstodo/movies/articles/2011/10/24/20111024puss-in-boots-review.html?nclick_check=1 |title='Puss in Boots,' 3.5 stars |publisher=The Arizona Republic |date=January 12, 2014 |accessdate=January 17, 2014}}</ref> Moira MacDonald of ''[[The Seattle Times]]'' gave the film three out of four stars, saying "I left dreaming of a world in which cats could tango - and when's the last time a movie did that?"<ref>{{cite web|last=Macdonald |first=Moira |url=http://seattletimes.com/html/movies/2016603499_mr28puss.html |title=Movies | 'Puss in Boots': Catnip for kids | Seattle Times Newspaper |publisher=Seattletimes.com |date=October 27, 2011 |accessdate=July 20, 2013}}</ref> Marjorie Baumgarten of ''[[The Austin Chronicle]]'' gave the film three out of five stars, saying "The seductive interplay of Banderas and Hayek, the barely recognizable vocal contributions of Galifianakis, and the Southern backwoods speech of Thornton and Sedaris all keep us attuned to the events on the screen."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.austinchronicle.com/calendar/film/2011-10-28/puss-in-boots/ |title=Puss in Boots - Film Calendar |publisher=The Austin Chronicle |date= |accessdate=November 1, 2013}}</ref>
Owen Gleiberman of ''[[Entertainment Weekly]]'' gave the film a C, saying "In the Shrek films, the joke of Puss in Boots, with his trilled consonants and penchant for chest-puffing sword duels, is that no one this cuddly should try to be this dashing. But in ''Puss in Boots'', that joke wears out its welcome in 15 minutes."<ref>{{cite news|author=Owen Gleiberman |url=http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0,,20518604,00.html |title=Puss in Boots Review | Movie Reviews and News |publisher=EW.com |date=November 1, 2011 |accessdate=July 20, 2013}}</ref> [[Ty Burr]] of ''[[The Boston Globe]]'' gave the film three out of four stars, saying "''Puss in Boots'' doesn't break any new ground in the storytelling department, and its reliance on go-go-go state-of-the-art action sequences grows wearying by the end, but the movie has a devilish wit that works for parent and child alike."<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.boston.com/ae/movies/articles/2011/10/28/puss_in_boots_soars_on_high_speed_action_and_antonio_banderas_as_one_cool_cat/?rss_id=Boston.com+--+Movie+news%3f |title="Puss in Boots" movie review - "Puss in Boots" showtimes - The Boston Globe |publisher=Boston.com |date=October 28, 2011 |accessdate=July 20, 2013 |first=Ty |last=Burr}}</ref> Elizabeth Weitzman of the ''[[New York Daily News]]'' gave the film four out of five stars, saying "It's always a pleasure to find a family film that respects its audience all the way up the line."<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/entertainment/tv-movies/puss-boots-review-antonio-banderas-feline-charmer-carries-entire-shrek-spinoff-article-1.968083 |title='Puss In Boots' review: Antonio Banderas' feline charmer carries entire 'Shrek' spinoff |publisher=NY Daily News |date=October 27, 2011 |accessdate=July 20, 2013 |location=New York}}</ref> Colin Covert of the ''[[Star Tribune]]'' gave the film one and a half stars out of four, saying "Remember that toy where you yank a string and hear the sound of a barnyard animal? "Puss in Boots" has about half as much entertainment value."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.startribune.com/entertainment/movies/132711188.html |title='Puss in Boots' has feline anemia |publisher=StarTribune.com |date=October 27, 2011 |accessdate=July 20, 2013}}</ref> Olly Richards of ''[[Empire (magazine)|Empire]]'' gave the film three out of five stars, saying "Like most kittens, it's not always perfectly behaved, but at least this new Puss adventure doesn't have you reaching for the cinematic spray bottle. And thank goodness the spin-off does nothing to neuter the charismatic cat's appeal."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.empireonline.com/reviews/reviewcomplete.asp?FID=10999 |title=Empire's Puss In Boots Movie Review |publisher=Empireonline.com |date= |accessdate=July 20, 2013}}</ref> Stan Hall of ''[[The Oregonian]]'' gave the film a B, saying "''Puss in Boots'' isn't particularly deep, nor does it take itself seriously -- it just wants to seek glory, win affection and cash in. Done, done and done."<ref>{{cite news|author=AP Photo/Paramount Pictures |url=http://www.oregonlive.com/movies/index.ssf/2011/10/shrek_spinoff_laps_up_laughs.html |title='Puss in Boots' review: 'Shrek' spinoff laps up laughs |publisher=OregonLive.com |date= October 27, 2011|accessdate=November 1, 2013}}</ref>
Kenneth Turan of the ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'' gave the film four out of five stars, saying "Perhaps the most engaging thing about "''Puss in Boots''" is that it never takes itself too seriously."<ref>{{cite news|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2011/oct/28/entertainment/la-et-puss-in-boots-20111028 |title=Movie review: 'Puss in Boots' - Los Angeles Times |publisher=Articles.latimes.com |date=October 28, 2011 |accessdate=July 20, 2013 |first1=Kenneth |last1=Turan}}</ref> Stephen Holden of ''[[The New York Times]]'' gave the film three and a half stars out of five, saying "It is a cheerfully chaotic jumble of fairy tale and nursery rhyme characters parachuted into a Spanish storybook setting."<ref>{{cite news|url=https://movies.nytimes.com/2011/10/28/movies/puss-in-boots-with-antonio-banderas-review.html?partner=rss&emc=rss&_r=0 |title=Puss in Boots (2011) |publisher=The New York Times |date=January 12, 2014 |accessdate=January 17, 2014 |first=Stephen |last=Holden}}</ref> Lou Lumenick of the ''[[New York Post]]'' gave the film one and a half stars out of four, saying "Basically, this toon is a tired riff on Sergio Leone's spaghetti Westerns, punctuated by more puns and cat jokes than you can shake a litter box at."<ref>{{cite news|last=Lumenick |first=Lou |url=http://www.nypost.com/p/entertainment/movies/feline_less_than_groovy_fYuVxeCTG5EyQqZNjZuh8I?CMP=OTC-rss&FEEDNAME= |title=Antonio Banderas voices 'Puss in Boots,' boring animated 'Shrek' spinoff |publisher=NYPOST.com |date=October 27, 2011 |accessdate=July 20, 2013}}</ref> Claudia Puig of ''[[USA Today]]'' gave the film three out of four stars, saying "With his impeccable comic timing and lyrical Spanish accent, Banderas' swashbuckling charmer is an undeniable treat."<ref>{{cite news|url=http://usatoday30.usatoday.com/life/movies/reviews/story/2011-10-27/puss-in-boots/50968494/1?csp=34life |title='Puss in Boots' is knee-high in family fun – USATODAY.com |publisher=Usatoday30.usatoday.com |date= October 28, 2011|accessdate=July 20, 2013}}</ref> Michael O'Sullivan of ''[[The Washington Post]]'' gave the film three out of four stars, saying "''Puss in Boots''" proves there is at least one cat with multiple lives. The feature-length animated spinoff - a star turn for the popular "Shrek" supporting character voiced by Antonio Banderas - is almost shockingly good. And not just because a lot of you will approach it with lowered expectations."<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/gog/movies/puss-in-boots,1158937/critic-review.html |title=Critic Review for Puss in Boots on |publisher=Washingtonpost.com |date=October 28, 2011 |accessdate=July 20, 2013}}</ref> Stephen Whitty of the ''[[Newark Star-Ledger]]'' gave the film three out of four stars, saying "An almost purr-fect little film that even a dog owner can enjoy."<ref>{{cite web|author=DreamWorks Animation |url=http://www.nj.com/entertainment/movies/index.ssf/2011/10/puss_in_boots_review_furry_swashbuckler_takes_center_stage.html |title='Puss in Boots' review: Furry swashbuckler takes center stage |publisher=NJ.com |date= |accessdate=July 20, 2013}}</ref>
Joe Morgenstern of ''[[The Wall Street Journal]]'' gave the film a positive review, saying "Puss made his debut in "''Shrek 2''," then did time in the two decreasingly funny sequels. Now he's got a movie of his own, and not a moment too soon."<ref>{{cite news|last=Morgenstern |first=Joe |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052970204644504576653060882783404 |title=Like Crazy | Puss in Boots | Anonymous | In Time | From Cupid's Blunders, Wonders | Film Reviews by Joe Morgenstern - WSJ.com |publisher=Online.wsj.com |date=October 28, 2011 |accessdate=July 20, 2013}}</ref> Lisa Kennedy of ''[[The Denver Post]]'' gave the film three out of four stars, saying "It would overstate matters to say Puss in Boots leaves its cat holding the bag (we had to get that in). But it also leaves its hero awaiting a richer fable, one befitting his charms and his portrayer's talents."<ref>{{cite news|last=Kennedy |first=Lisa |url=http://www.denverpost.com/movies/ci_19200730 |title=Movie review: "Puss in Boots" plies its puns with catlike dexterity |publisher=The Denver Post |date= October 28, 2011|accessdate=July 20, 2013}}</ref> Anna Smith of ''[[Time Out (magazine)|Time Out]]'' gave the film three out of five stars, saying "''Puss in Boots'' is uneven, but when it's on course, cat fans will be in heaven."<ref>{{cite web|author=Anna Smith |url=http://www.timeout.com/london/film/puss-in-boots |title=Puss in Boots | review, synopsis, book tickets, showtimes, movie release date | Time Out London |publisher=Timeout.com |date=December 6, 2011 |accessdate=July 20, 2013}}</ref> Amy Biancolli of the ''[[Houston Chronicle]]'' gave the film three out of five stars, saying "''Puss in Boots'' prances along on three basic truths. One, cats are funny. Two, vain Spanish cats in high-heeled musketeer boots are even funnier. Lastly, booted, vain Spanish cats voiced by a breathy Antonio Banderas are flat-out hilarious."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://events.chron.com/reviews/show/14080384-review-puss-in-boots |title=Review of Puss in Boots - 29-95.com |publisher=Events.chron.com |date= |accessdate=July 20, 2013}}</ref> Tasha Robinson of ''[[The A.V. Club]]'' gave the film a C+, saying "''Puss In Boots'' makes a great theme-park ride, a thrill-a-minute feast for the eyes and the semicircular canals. But while the settings are impressively multidimensional, the characters are flatter than old-school cel drawings."<ref>{{cite web|last=Robinson |first=Tasha |url=http://www.avclub.com/articles/puss-in-boots,64062/ |title=Puss In Boots | Film | Movie Review |publisher=The A.V. Club |date=October 27, 2011 |accessdate=July 20, 2013}}</ref>

Film Journalists]]<ref>{{cite news|last=Cornet|first=Roth|title='The Artist' leads with 9 Alliance of Women Journalists nominations|url=http://www.hitfix.com/blogs/in-contention/posts/the-artist-leads-with-9-alliance-of-women-journalists-nominations|accessdate=January 19, 2014|newspaper=Hitfix|date=December 23, 2011}}</ref> |Best Animated Film | |- |Best Animated Female |[[Salma Hayek]] |- | rowspan=9|[[39th Annie Awards|Annie Awards]]<ref>{{cite web|title=39th Annual Annie Nominations & Area Film Critics Association Awards 2011|Washington D.C. Area Film Critics Association Awards]]<ref>{{cite web|title=The 2011 WAFCA Awards|url=http://www.dcfilmcritics.com/awards/2011.htm|publisher=The Washington D.C. Area Film Critics Association|accessdate=January 19, 2014|date=December 5, 2011}}</ref> |Best Animated Feature | |- |[[Women Film Critics Circle]]<ref>{{cite news|last=Cornet|first=Roth|title=Women critics like 'The Help,' 'Iron Lady' and 'Whistleblower'|url=http://www.hitfix.com/blogs/in-contention/posts/women-critics-like-the-help-iron-lady-and-whistleblower|accessdate=January 19, 2014|newspaper=Hitfix|date=December 20, 2012}}</ref> |Best Animated Females | |{{won}} |- |}
===Home media=== ''Puss in Boots'' was released on DVD, Blu-ray and Blu-ray 3D on February 24, 2012. The movie was accompanied by a short animated film called ''[[Puss in Boots: The Three Diablos]]''.<ref name="DVD">{{cite news|last=Zahed|first=Ramin|title=Check Out Exclusive Clip from "Puss In Boots"|url=http://www.animationmagazine.net/home_entertainment/check-out-exclusive-clip-from-puss-in-boots/|accessdate=February 26, 2012|newspaper=Animation Magazine|date=February 17, 2012}}</ref> As of July 2013, 7.2 million home entertainment units were sold worldwide.<ref>{{cite news|title=DreamWorks Animation Reports Second Quarter 2013 Financial Results|url=http://ir.dreamworksanimation.com/releasedetail.cfm?ReleaseID=781777|accessdate=August 3, 2013|newspaper=DreamWorks Animation|date=July 31, 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130803122514/http://ir.dreamworksanimation.com/releasedetail.cfm?ReleaseID=781777|archivedate=August 3, 2013|df=mdy-all}}</ref>
Another featured extra short is "Klepto Kitty"; a three-minute profile of [[Dusty the Klepto Kitty]], a notorious cat in California who steals items from neighbors' yards, some of it captured on a night vision kitty-cam, hung around Dusty's neck by the [[Animal Planet]] network for their own documentary.<ref name="klepto">{{cite web|title=Klepto's Owners Find Out How He Operates|url=http://abc7news.com/archive/8874860/|publisher=ABC News: San Francisco 7 News|accessdate=14 June 2016|author=Vic Lee|date=5 November 2012}}</ref>
==Expanded franchise== ===Sequel/Reboot=== In November 2012, executive producer [[Guillermo del Toro]] said that they already did a couple of script drafts for a sequel, and that the director [[Chris Miller (animator)|Chris Miller]] wants to take Puss on an adventure to exotic places.<ref name="Collider">{{cite news|last=Chitwood|first=Adam|title=Guillermo del Toro Talks PUSS IN BOOTS 2, KUNG FU PANDA 3 & TROLLHUNTERS; Says PANDA 3 Has the "Most Formidable Villain in the Series"|url=http://collider.com/puss-in-boots-2-sequel-kung-fu-panda-3-guillermo-del-toro/210271/|accessdate=November 12, 2012|newspaper=Collider.com|date=November 12, 2012}}</ref> In April 2014, Antonio Banderas, the voice of Puss, said that the work on the sequel had just begun.<ref>{{cite web|last=Chitwood|first=Adam|title=Antonio Banderas Says He Just Started Work on PUSS IN BOOTS 2|url=http://collider.com/puss-in-boots-2-news-antonio-banderas/|publisher=Collider.com|accessdate=April 16, 2014|date=April 16, 2014}}</ref> In June 2014, the movie was titled ''Puss in Boots 2: Nine Lives & 40 Thieves'' and was scheduled to be released on November 2, 2018.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.comingsoon.net/news/movienews.php?id=119483 |title=Dates Set for Madagascar 4, The Croods 2, Puss in Boots 2, Captain Underpants, and Hitman |publisher=ComingSoon.net |date= |accessdate=June 12, 2014}}</ref> Two months later, it was moved back to December 21, 2018.<ref name=CSShiftsTwo>{{cite web|title=DreamWorks Animation Shifts Two Sequels Back Slightly|url=http://www.comingsoon.net/news/movienews.php?id=122167|publisher=ComingSoon.net|accessdate=August 22, 2014|date=August 21, 2014}}</ref> In January 2015, ''Puss in Boots 2'' was removed from the release schedule following corporate restructuring and DreamWorks Animation's new policy to release two films a year.<ref name=DeadlineCut500Jobs>{{cite news|url=http://deadline.com/2015/01/dreamworks-animation-restructuring-to-cut-500-jobs-with-290m-charge-1201355918/|last=Lieberman|first=David|title=DreamWorks Animation Restructuring To Cut 500 Jobs With $290M Charge|website=[[Deadline Hollywood]]|date=January 22, 2015|accessdate=January 25, 2015}}</ref><ref name="BOMNewDates2017-01-27">{{cite web|title=New Dates & Changes|url=http://boxofficemojo.com:80/schedule/?view=changes&p=.htm|publisher=Box Office Mojo|accessdate=April 27, 2017|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150127074138/http://boxofficemojo.com/schedule/?view=changes&p=.htm|archivedate=January 27, 2015|deadurl=yes|df=mdy-all}}</ref> Two months later, Banderas said in an interview that the script was under restructuring, and that Shrek may appear in the film.<ref>{{cite news|last1=de Semlyen|first1=Phil|title=Shrek To Return For Puss In Boots 2?|url=http://www.empireonline.com/news/story.asp?NID=43826|accessdate=March 28, 2015|work=Empire|date=March 27, 2015}}</ref>
On November 6, 2018, it was reported by [[Variety (magazine)|Variety]] that [[Chris Meledandri]] had been tasked to reboot both ''Shrek'' and ''Puss in Boots'', with the original cast potentially returning.<ref name=ShrekReboot/><ref name=ShrekRebootAnimation/>
===Animated series=== {{main|The Adventures of Puss in Boots}} The film also spawned an animated series that premiered on [[Netflix]] on January 16, 2015.<ref name=PRNLegendaryPanache>{{cite press release|title=Puss in Boots And King Julien Add Their Legendary Panache To DreamWorks Animation's Netflix Original Series Line-Up|url=http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/puss-in-boots-and-king-julien-add-their-legendary-panache-to-dreamworks-animations-netflix-original-series-line-up-250055181.html|publisher=PR Newswire|accessdate=March 13, 2014|author=DreamWorks Animation|date=March 13, 2014}}</ref>
==Video games== *''[[Puss in Boots (video game)|Puss in Boots]]'', a video game based on the film, developed by [[Blitz Games]], and published by [[THQ]] on October 25, 2011 for [[Xbox 360]], [[PlayStation 3]], [[Wii]], and [[Nintendo DS]].<ref>{{cite web|title=DreamWorks' Puss in Boots|url=http://www.thq.com/us/dreamworks-puss-in-boots/|work=THQ|accessdate=September 22, 2011}}</ref> It features support for [[Kinect]] and [[PlayStation Move]] on the respective platforms.<ref>{{cite news|title=Step into the Boots of the Swashbuckling Feline Hero with the Puss in Boots Video Game from THQ|url=http://www.businesswire.com/news/home/20110928005523/en/Step-Boots-Swashbuckling-Feline-Hero-Puss-Boots|accessdate=October 2, 2011|newspaper=THQ ''via'' Business Wire|date=September 28, 2011}}</ref> *''Fruit Ninja: Puss in Boots'', a ''Puss in Boots''-themed ''[[Fruit Ninja]]'' video game, which was released on October 20, 2011, on the [[App Store (iOS)|iOS App Store]],<ref>{{cite news|last=Gilbert|first=Ben|title=Fruit Ninja: Puss in Boots is a thing, really; coming to iOS on Oct. 20|url=http://www.joystiq.com/2011/10/07/fruit-ninja-puss-in-boots-is-a-thing-really-coming-to-ios-on/|accessdate=October 7, 2011|newspaper=Joystiq|date=October 7, 2011}}</ref> and was released for [[Android (operating system)|Android]] devices on November 28, 2011, on the Amazon Appstore.<ref>{{cite news|last=Hinkle|first=David|title=Fruit Ninja: Puss in Boots heading to Android on Monday|url=http://www.joystiq.com/2011/11/25/fruit-ninja-puss-in-boots-heading-to-android-on-monday/|accessdate=November 25, 2011|newspaper=Joystiq|date=November 25, 2011}}</ref>

{{Infobox film | name = Rudo y Cursi | image = Poster rudo y cursi.jpg | caption = Original Theatrical Poster | director = [[Carlos Cuarón]] | producer = [[Alfonso Cuarón]]
[[Alejandro González Iñárritu]]
[[Guillermo del Toro]] | writer = Carlos Cuarón | narrator = [[Guillermo Francella]] | starring = [[Gael García Bernal]]
[[Diego Luna]]
[[Guillermo Francella]] | music = [[Leoncio Lara]] | cinematography = Adam Kimmel | editing = [[Álex Rodríguez (film editor)|Alex Rodríguez]] | studio = [[Cha Cha Cha Films]]
[[Focus Features]]
[[Esperanto Filmoj]]
Producciones Anhelo
[[Canana Films]] | distributor = [[Universal Pictures]] (Mexico)
[[Sony Pictures Classics]] (United States) | released = {{start date|2008|12|19}} | runtime = 103 minutes | country = Mexico | language = [[Spanish language|Spanish]] | budget = | gross = $11.2 million }} '''''Rudo y Cursi''''' ([[Spanish language|Spanish]], literally, "Rough and Corny") is a 2008 [[Cinema of Mexico|Mexican film]] starring [[Diego Luna]], [[Gael García Bernal]] and [[Guillermo Francella]]. It is directed by [[Carlos Cuarón]] and produced by [[Cha Cha Cha Films]]. It is Carlos Cuarón's first full-length movie. == Plot summary == In the fictional farming village of Tachatlán, in the [[Cihuatlan|Cihuatlán Valley]] of [[Jalisco]], [[Mexico]], young men dream of escaping the drudgery of the banana plantations. Two of them, a pair of half-brothers, play in local [[association football|football]] matches. Tato (Gael Garcia) is the star striker and Beto (Diego Luna) is the eccentric goalkeeper. During one match they are spotted by a talent scout (Guillermo Francella) and he offers one of them the opportunity to go to [[Mexico City]] with him and try out for one of the country's big teams. As the scout's roster is already full, he says he can only take one of the brothers and they decide to settle it on a penalty shot. Tato scores the penalty against his brother, therefore earning the right to head to the capital. == Cast == * [[Gael García Bernal]] as Tato "Cursi" Verdusco * [[Diego Luna]] as Beto "Rudo" Verdusco * [[Guillermo Francella]] as Darío "Batuta" Vidali * [[Dolores Heredia]] as Elvira * [[Joaquín Cosio]] as Arnulfo * [[Adriana Paz]] as Toña ==Production== Carlos Cuarón first formed the idea for the film while on a promotional tour for ''[[Y tu mamá también]]''. He initially planned for only one character, but later decided to include a brother. Principal photography began in summer 2007 in [[Cihuatlán]], [[Mexico]]. The banana plantation where the brothers work in the film is actually owned by the Cuarón family. For his role Bernal wore blonde extensions to lengthen his hair while Luna dyed his hair black and grew a mustache to play the older brother. Additional filming took place in [[México City]] and [[Toluca]].{{cite web|url=http://www.elpais.com/articulo/cine/Mexico/platanero/elpepuculcin/20070629elpepicin_4/Tes|title=México en un platanero|author=Chiara Arroyo|date=29 June 2007|work=[[El País]]|accessdate=11 January 2010|language=Spanish}} ==Release== ''Rudo y Cursi'' released on December 2008 in Mexico. It premiered internationally at the April 2009 [[San Francisco International Film Festival]] and was screened at the 2009 [[Sundance Film Festival]] and the [[Tribeca Film Festival]]. It was released generally, on a limited basis, on May 8, 2009. It was released on DVD and Blu-ray Disc on August 25, 2009. ===Box office=== ''Rudo y Cursi'' was very successful at the box office. It became the sixth top grossing Mexican movie of all time.{{cite web |url=https://variety.com/2009/film/news/mexican-market-grows-ups-output-1118001175/ |title=Mexican market grows, ups output |first=James |last=Young |date= 12 March 2009 |website=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]] |accessdate=2013-09-19}} In its first two weeks in the US, it earned $738,706 on 219 screens.{{cite news |url=http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/n/a/2009/05/17/entertainment/e093437D51.DTL |title= 'Angels & Demons,' 'Star Trek' dominate box office |agency=[[Associated Press|AP]] |date= 18 May 2009 |work=[[San Francisco Chronicle]] |accessdate=11 January 2010}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}} It eventually grossed $9,264,208 in overseas earnings, bringing its worldwide total to $11,091,868.{{cite web|url= http://boxofficemojo.com/movies/?id=rudoycursi.htm |title= Rudo Y Cursi |publisher=Box Office Mojo |accessdate=11 January 2010}} ==References== {{reflist}} == External links == * {{official website|http://www.rudoycursilapelicula.com}} * [https://web.archive.org/web/20081210014533/http://www.biosstars-mx.com/pelicula/2008/r/rudo_y_cursi.html Rudo y Cursi video, news and trailer at Biosstars International database] * {{IMDb title|0405393}} * {{AllRovi movie|405000|Rudo y Cursi}} * {{rotten-tomatoes|rudo_y_cursi}} {{Alfonso Cuarón}} {{Guillermo del Toro}} [[Category:2008 films]] [[Category:2000s drama films]] [[Category:Cha Cha Cha Films films]] [[Category:Sony Pictures Classics films]] [[Category:Cinema of Mexico]] [[Category:Films produced by Guillermo del Toro]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox award | name = Sarasaviya Awards | current_awards = 34th Sarasaviya Awards | image = File:SarasaviyaAward.jpg | alt = | caption = Trophy of the award | description = Excellence in cinematic achievements | presenter = [[Associated Newspapers of Ceylon Limited]] | country = [[Sri Lanka]] | year = May 9, 1964 | year2 = {{Start date|df=y|2018|08|03}} | website = {{URL|http://www.sarasaviyaawards.com/}} }}
'''''Sarasaviya Awards''''' (Sinhala:'''සරසවිය සම්මාන''') is an award bestowed to distinguished individuals involved with the [[Cinema of Sri Lanka|Sinhala cinema]], each year by the Sarasaviya weekly newspaper in collaboration with the [[Associated Newspapers of Ceylon Limited]] (Lake House), [[Sri Lanka]] in recognition of the contributions made by them to the [[Cinema of Sri Lanka|Sri Lankan film industry]]. The Sarasaviya ceremony is one of the oldest film events in Sri Lanka. The awards were first introduced in 1964.<ref>http://www.sundayobserver.lk/2007/03/25/mag09.asp</ref><ref>http://www.dailynews.lk/2003/09/05/new15.html</ref> The Sarasaviya Awards have been often referred to as the Sinhala Cinema industry's equivalent to [[Academy Awards|The Oscars]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Feature|url=http://archives.dailynews.lk/2005/11/05/fea10.htm|work=archives.dailynews.lk}}</ref>
==History== The Sarasaviya film awards ceremony began in 1964 at a time when the local cinema was trying to shed its [[South Indian]] orientation and establish an indigenous identity. There was no need to go to [[India]] to make films any more and the era of Indian artistes too had ended.
The first Sarasaviya film festival was held on May 9, 1964 at the Asoka Cinema Hall, [[Colombo]], 17 years after the first [[Cinema of Sri Lanka|Sinhala film]] screened. By then a series of good Sinhala films like Podi Putha, Rekhawa, Sandeshaya, Ranmuthuduwa, Kurulubedda, Sikurutharuwa and Gamperaliya had appeared on screen. Yet the mainstream consisted of simulations of Indian productions.
The year 1960 is seen as the beginning of the golden era of Sinhala cinema. The first Sarasaviya Awards Festival had as entries not only the films screened in 1963 but also the films screened from 1960 to 1963. The best film, best director, best script-writer, best actor and best actress were honoured that day. [[Gamperaliya (film)|Gamperaliya]] was regarded as the best film and it was awarded to its producer Anton Wickremasinghe. Sir Lester James Peiris and [[Regi Siriwardena]] won the awards for best director and best script-writer, respectively and that too was for Gamperaliya. D.R. Nanayakkara was awarded the best actor title for his performance in Sikuru Tharuwa, another popular film in the 1964 film festival. The best actress award was received by [[Punya Heendeniya]] for her performance in Gamperaliya.
===Suspension and 2016 resumption=== The awards festival was suspended by the Rajapaksa administration and were resumed in 2016 after Minister [[Gayantha Karunathilaka]] announced that the festival will resume under the new government.<ref>{{cite web|title=2016 Sarasaviya Awards|url=http://www.sarasaviya.lk/2016/12/01/?fn=sa1612012|website=www.sarasaviya.lk}}</ref>
==Awards at present== In 2004, there were 33 awards in total, including the 12 prominent awards. However, this varies from year to year. Following is a brief list of the Award winners from each category for each year since 1964.
===Prominent awards===
* [[Sarasaviya Best Film Award|Best Picture]] * [[Sarasaviya Best Director Award|Best Director]] * [[Sarasaviya Best Actor Award|Best Actor]] * [[Sarasaviya Best Actress Award|Best Actress]] * [[Sarasaviya Best Supporting Actor Award|Best Supporting Actor]] * [[Sarasaviya Best Supporting Actress Award|Best Supporting Actress]] * [[Sarasaviya Best Emerging Actor Award|Best Emerging Actor]] * [[Sarasaviya Best Emerging Actress Award|Best Emerging Actress]] * [[Sarasaviya Best Music Direction Award|Best Original Score]] * [[Sarasaviya Best Male Playback Singer Award|Best Male Singer]] * [[Sarasaviya Best Female Playback Singer|Best Female Singer]] * [[Sarasaviya Best Lyricist Award|Best Song Lyricist]]
===Awards based on popularvote=== * [[Sarasaviya Most Popular Actor Award|Best Popular Actor]] * [[Sarasaviya Most Popular Actress Award|Best Popular Actress]] * [[Sarasaviya Most Popular Film Award|Best Popular Film]]
===Technical awards=== * [[Sarasaviya Best Art Direction Award|Best Production Design]] * [[Sarasaviya Best Cinematographer Award|Best Cinematography]] * [[Sarasaviya Best Editor Award|Best Editing]] * [[Sarasaviya Best Script Writer Award|Best Screenplay]] * [[Sarasaviya Best Sound Effects Award|Best Sound]] * [[Sarasaviya Best Makeup Artist Award|Best Makeup]]
===Lifetime awards=== * [[Rana Thisara Awards]]
===Special awards=== * [[Ranapala Bodhinagoda Memorial Literary Awards]] * [[Special Jury Awards]] * [[Other Special Awards]] * [[Lester James Pieris Awards]]
===Talent awards=== * [[Merit Awards]]
==Winners and nominees of past Sarasaviya Awards== * [[33rd Sarasaviya Awards]] (held in 2016) * [[34th Sarasaviya Awards]] (held in 2018)
==References== {{Reflist}}
{{Sarasaviya Awards}}

{{unreferenced|date=August 2014}} {{Infobox comic book title |title = Star Trek: Khan |image = |imagesize = 200px |alt = |caption = |schedule = Monthly |limited = y |SciFi = y |publisher = [[IDW Publishing]] |date = October 2013 – February 2014 |issues = 5 |main_char_team = |writers = Mike Johnson
[[Roberto Orci]] (consultant) |artists = [[David Messina]]
Claudia Balboni (#1-3)
Luca Lamberti (#3-4) |pencillers = |inkers = Marina Castelvetro (#1-3)
Giorgia Sposito (#4-5) |letterers = Neil Uyetake |colorists = |editors = Sarah Gaydos |creative_team_month = |creative_team_year = |creators = [[Gene Roddenberry]] |TPB = Star Trek: Khan |ISBN = 1613778953 |subcat = IDW Publishing |sort = Star Trek: Khan }} '''''Star Trek: Khan''''' is a five-issue [[comic book]] [[prequel]] and [[sequel]] to the 2013 film ''[[Star Trek Into Darkness]]'' by [[IDW Publishing]]. It follows [[Khan Noonien Singh]], explaining his past and how he came to have a change in facial appearance and serve Admiral Alexander Marcus. ==Plot== {{expand-section|date=September 2017}} ===Issue one=== Starts with the trial of Khan Noonien Singn on stardate 2259.246 (September 3, 2259). Khan is brought forward, where he states that he rejects the court's authority. But Kirk note that the defendant calling himself Khan, looks nothing like the records of Khan Noonien Singn and ask him who him really is. Starting in New Delhi on November 1971. A group of children are gassed and taken by masked men. A year later, January 1972, Doctor Heisen is talking to a group of investors to invest in his Eugenics experiment to create super soldiers. Heisen then takes a look at his test subjects, 24 boys and 15 girls, where he notices one with one leg being picked and notices his fury when he beats them. A year later, Dr. Heisen is in his office with the crippled boy who is seen to have regrown his leg through the genetic experiments that have been performed on him. Heisen shows the boy his computer and explains how he wishes for the boy to use it to unlock all of the knowledge of the world, the boy named Noonien Singh. By 1979 all the children make progress in intellectual and physical prowess. Doctor Heisen observe a sparring session between Noonien and another boy using real knives. After scratching the other boy and seeing his wounds heal instantly, Noonien tests his own regenerative powers by impaling himself with both of his knives. While in a recovery room, Noonien hacks into the facility’s security system and disables in, then proceeds to escape by digging out through the solid rock floor. Dr. Heisen goes to retrieve Noonien from the Gobi desert by incapacitating him using a neural inhibitor that has been implanted into all of the subjects. On August, 1985 Noonien Singn presents Heisen with a box filled with all of the students removed neural inhibitors. He crushes Dr. Heisen’s skull with his bare hands before informing his companions that the world is waiting for them. {{Star Trek publications}} {{Star Trek reboot series}} [[Category:2014 comics debuts]] [[Category:Comics based on Star Trek]] [[Category:Prequel comics]] [[Category:Sequel comics]] {{IDW-Publishing-comic-book-stub}} {{StarTrek-stub}}

{{Infobox card game | title =Sticheln | subtitle = | image_link = File:Bavarian pack-Suit of Leaves.jpg | image_caption =''The suit of Leaves in a German pack'' | alt_names = | type = [[Plain-trick game]] | players = 4 | ages = | num_cards = 32 | deck = German | play = Anti-clockwise | card_rank = A K O U 10 9 8 7 | origin = [[Germany]] | related = | playing_time = | random_chance = | skills = | footnotes = }} '''Sticheln''' is an easy-to-learn, [[trick-taking]], [[card game]] for 4 players that originated from [[Germany]]. It is an old game, being recorded as early in 1846.<ref name=AKS>Allgemeines Karten-Spielbuch (1846), p. 276.</ref>
== Description == Sticheln has been described as "a very simple card game, which does not need exceptional mental agility to learn quickly - perhaps the reason why it counts so many friends."<ref name=AKS/> It is similar to [[Whist]], but played individually rather than in teams, using a [[shortened pack]] and a different scoring system. It is a 4-hander and is played either with a [[French playing cards|French-suited]] [[Piquet]] deck or [[German playing cards]]. Cards rank in their natural order: Ace/Sow, King, Queen/Ober, Jack/Unter, Ten, Nine, Eight, Seven.
After cutting the pack to decide on the seating order and dealer will be, the dealer pays eight tokens to the pot. He then shuffles the pack and the player to his left cuts it. The bottom card of the top packet is turned as trumps – it belongs to the dealer – then each player is dealt eight cards in two packets of four in anti-clockwise order. [[Forehand (card player)|Forehand]] leads to the first trick. Thereafter the trick winner leads to the next one. Players must follow suit, trump if unable, or play any card if they cannot follow or trump. Players must head the trick if possible.
For each trick won, players receive one token from the pot. Forehand becomes the new dealer and pays his eight tokens to the pot.
The game continues either for a pre-agreed number of rounds (each round being 4 deals) or when one player reaches an agreed number of tokens.
== Modern Sticheln == In 1993, a new game marketed as Sticheln was launched in Germany. It used proprietary cards and bore no resemblance to the original game of Sticheln.<ref>[http://islaythedragon.com/guides/tricked-out-a-guide-to-trick-taking/ ''Tricked-Out!''] at islaythedragon.com. Retrieved 31 Oct 2018</ref>
== References == {{Reflist}}
== Literature == * ''Allgemeines Karten-Spielbuch'', 2nd edn., Franz Tendler, Vienna, 1846. * ''Verstand und Glück im Bunde. Ein theoretisch-practisches Spielbuch.'' Tendler, Vienna, 1830.
{{Trick-taking card games}} [[Category:Austrian card games]] [[Category:German deck card games]] [[Category:Four-player card games]] [[Category:Plain-trick games]]
